member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber

summary.para: The Teradata Database 14.0 and later supports a data type called NUMBER. This data type supports fixed point decimal (Fixed Decimal) and floating point (Floating Decimal) numbers. Fixed decimals can support up to 38 significant digits. Floating decimals can support up 40 digits, however, the precision of the number is guaranteed only up to 38 digits.
TdNumber is the equivalent Provider Specific Type to NUMBER. The range of TdNumber is +/-[1E-130 to 9.99...9E125] as well as 0. It will also support a precision of up to 40 digits.
TdNumber can also be used to receive and send numbers from and to the Teradata Database.

remarks.para: A number is stored in the following format:
The "X.XXXX..." represents the mantissa, and the "YYY" is the exponent (as a power of 10) of the number.
TdNumber supports arithmetic, comparison, and conversion methods .

TdNumber is similar to TdDecimal. The differences between these two types is that TdNumber can support a precision of up to 40 digits, and floating point numbers are supported. A TdDecimal can be implicitly converted to a TdNumber. A TdNumber must be explicitly converted to a TdDecimal.
A TdNumber value can be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. The following is an example of using TdNumber as a parameter to a Store Procedure.

member.summary: The maximum value of a TdNumber. The value is 9.999999999999999999999999999999999999999e+125.

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.MinValue
member.summary: The minimum value of a TdNumber. The value is -9.999999999999999999999999999999999999999e+125.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.#ctor(System.Int32[],System.Int16)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of TdNumber from an array of Int32 that represents the data components that defines the number.

remarks.para: The represents the mantissa of the number. When the components of the mantissa are determined, the mantissa must be converted into a scaled integer, and the exponent must be adjusted. The array must contain 5 elements. The order of the components in the array must start from the least to the most significant.
When a number is normalized, the exponent can range from -130 to 125. However, the mantissa must be represented as scaled integer. There the range of is -169 to 86.
The following is an example of setting up the array that represents the mantissa of the number, and then invoking this constructor:

member.param: The array that contains the components of the number.
The exponent of the Floating decimal.
member.exception: The array must contain 5 components.
The number of digits in the mantissa cannot exceed 40, or the exponent is not between -130 and 125.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of TdNumber from the data components that are passed in as several Int32 parameters.

member.param: The second least significant number component.
The second most significant number component.
member.exception: The number represented by the data components is too large to be represented by a TdNumber.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.op_Explicit(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber)~Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDecimal
member.summary: Converts a TdNumber to a TdDecimal.

remarks.para: If the number contained in is very close to zero, the TdDecimal instance that is returned will be zero. For example, suppose an instance of TdNumber contains the number 9.231356e-50. When this number is converted into an instance of TdDecimal, the number that the instance contains is zero. The reason for this is that the maximum precision of a TdDecimal is 38, and the first 38 digits that are to the right of the decimal point of the number are all zeroes.

member.param: The TdNumber that will be converted.
member.returns: A TdDecimal is returned.
member.exception: The number represented by cannot be contained in a TdDecimal.

member.summary: Converts a TdNumber to A System.Char.
member.exception: The value of the TdNumber is Null.
A Char cannot hold the value of the TdNumber.
member.returns: A Char is returned.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.op_Explicit(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber)~System.Double
member.summary: Converts a TdNumber to a System.Double.
member.returns: A Double is returned.

remarks.para: When a TdNumber is converted into a System.Double a rounding error may occur.

The reason for this is that the mantissa of a has a precision of 16 digits. A TdNumber has a precision of 40 digits. When a TdNumber is converted to a System.Double, it will be truncated at the 17th position from the left.

member.exception: The value of the TdNumber is Null.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Converts this instance to its equivalent String representation using the specified format and culture-specific format information.
member.param: An IFormatProvider that supplies culture-specific formatting information.
member.returns: The String representation of this instance as specified by format and provider.
member.exception: An incorrect format specifier is contained in the format string.

remarks.para: The format string is specified as
A null can be passed in as the format string. When this is done, the 'G' is used as the Format Specifier.
The maximum number of digits that will appear in the string conversion of a TdNumber is 40.
The following Format Specifiers are supported:

description.para: Currency. Before the number gets converted into a string that represents currency, it is expanded (the exponent is applied to the mantissa). The precision specifier is applied to the digits that are to the right of the decimal point. For example, when the number 6.8737251092e5 is converted and "C4" is specified as the , the result is "$687372.5109".

Exponential notation. The precision specifier is used to indicate how many digits are to appear to the right of the decimal point. For example, when the number 9.3413442e-50 is converted to a string and "E3" is specified as the , the result is "9.341e-050".

Fixed numeric Format. Before the number gets converted into a string, it is expanded (the exponent is applied to the mantissa). After the number is expanded, the precision specifier is applied to the digits that are to the right of the decimal point. For example, when the number 3.45495874721e4 is converted to a string and "F2" is specified as the , the result is "34549.59".
Number format. The exponent is applied to the mantissa. After the number has been expanded the group and decimal separators are added to the numeric string.

remarks.para: The Precision Specifier indicates how many decimal places will appear in the string. It does not have to be specified. A valid Precision Specifier is between 0 - 99.
For more information on each of the supported Format Specifiers please refer to Standard Numeric Format Strings in MSDN.
When a number is converted to a string, its format is controlled by the . For each specifier, this object contains formatting information that will be used when constructing the numeric string.
Custom format strings are not currently supported by TdNumber.

example.para: The following is an example on formatting a TdNumber when converting to a String.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.ToDecimal(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber)
member.summary: Converts the value of the specified TdNumber to the equivalent .
member.param: The TdNumber that is to be converted to a System.Decimal value.
member.returns: A System.Decimal value that is equivalent to the TdNumber is returned.
member.exception: The TdNumber value is Null.
The TdNumber could not be converted to a System.Decimal.

remarks.para: An instance of a TdNumber will be converted into a System.Decimal only when the number of significant digits (digits to the left of the decimal point) of the number is less than 29. If the precision of the number is greater than 29, the scale will be truncated so that the number will fit within the System.Decimal.
What is meant by number is the representation of the floating decimal without the exponent. For example if an instance of TdNumber represents 2.938174e-4, the number is 0.00002938174.

System.Decimal stores numbers as a scaled integer. It can support a number with a maximum precision of 29, maximum scale of 28, and a number in the range of minus or plus 79,228,162,514,264,337,593,543,950,335. A scaled integer representation of a number is the number without any decimal separator. For example, the scale integer representation of 43567.90843 is 4356790843. The range of valid numbers also applies to the numbers' scaled integer representation.

Due to these characteristics of a System.Decimal, a TdNumber instance that is in the valid range may not fit into a System.Decimal unless it is truncated. These TdNumber instances will have an actual precision of 29 and a scale greater than 0. It's scaled integer representation will also be outside the valid range of the scaled integer representation of a System.Decimal.

The following example displays two numbers that are within the range of valid System.Decimal values. However, their scale integer representation falls outside the range of the scaled integer range of the maximum System.Decimal value.
In order to perform a conversion to System.Decimal, these numbers will be truncated one decimal place.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.GetBytes
member.summary: The binary representation of this TdNumber structure is returned as an array of bytes.
member.returns: The mantissa and exponent are returned as an array of bytes.

remarks.para: Five unsigned 32 bit integers are used internally to store the mantissa of a number, and a signed 16 bit integer is used to store the exponent.

In the byte array, the data for the mantissa will begin at the 0 (zero) element, and the exponent will begin at the 21 element of the array. It will take 20 bytes to represent the mantissa, and 2 bytes for the exponent. The total number of elements in the array will be 22.

When the binary representation is generated, The decimal point will be removed, and the exponent will adjusted. After this is done, the five unsigned 32 bit integers of the mantissa and the signed 16 bit of the exponent are converted to a byte array. The least significant byte of the mantissa will appear in the first element of the array.

member.exception: The value of the TdDecimal is Null.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdNumber.GetBits
member.summary: The binary representation of the value of this TdNumber structure is returned as an array of signed integers.
member.returns: An array that contains the number components and exponent is returned. The decimal point is removed from the mantissa and the exponent is adjusted. See for more information.
member.remarks:
The array that is returned will contain 6 elements:
data[0] contains the low order bits.
data[1 - 3] contains the middle order bits.
data[4] contains the high order bits
data[5] contains the exponent.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdXml
member.summary: TdXml represents a Xml data type. It is used to retrieve Xml data from a Teradata Database.

remarks.para: TdXml does not expose any public constructor. It's primary purpose is to retreive Xml data from a Teradata database.

In order to create an instance of TdXml, must be called when the data contained in a Xml column is to be retrieved. Once a TdXml instance has been created the method is called to create a . The XmlReader is used to access the Xml data that is returned from a Teradata Database.

When a XmlReader is created, the provider will open a request on the existing connection. This request is separate and independent from the request that was opened to process the query. A Teradata Database has a maximum number of open requests that it can support per a connection. The limit is 16.
It is important that is called after the XmlReader has been used to process the Xml. This will free up the request that was used to retrieve the Xml from the Teradata Database.

A TdXml instance can only be created when the Xml data is retrieved using deferred mode. This allows the data to be streamed from the database to the provider, and allows an application to retrieve the data in chunks.
An application is unable to access the base stream of the TdXml instance.
Xml data is returned using deferred mode when has not been specified in the call to .

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve the Xml contained in an Xml column.
The Xml that is used in this example is

para.code: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <customers> <customer> <Name id="1234">John Hancock</Name> <Address>100 1st Street One City, CA 12345</Address> <Phone1>(999)9999-999</Phone1> <Phone2>(999)9999-998</Phone2> <Fax>(999)9999-997</Fax> <Email>John@somecompany.com</Email> <order Number="NW-01-16366" Date="Feb/28/2001"> <Contact>Mary</Contact> <Phone>(987)6543-210</Phone> <ShipTo>Some company 2467 Pioneer Road Globecity, Globeland, 1000</ShipTo> <SubTotal>2355</SubTotal> <Tax>141.50</Tax> <Total>2496.50</Total> <item ID="001"> <Quantity>10</Quantity> <PartNumber>F54709</PartNumber> <Description/> <UnitPrice>29.50</UnitPrice> <Price>295.00</Price> </item> </order> </customer> </customers>

member.para: TdXml can be marshalled across application domains. However, the cannot be marshalled. The TdXml.CreateXmlReader method returns an XmlReader. When this method is called from a TdXml instance that has been marshalled, a exception will be thrown.
The property must be used when retrieving the Xml data using a TdXml instance that has been marshalled to another application domain. This property will return the Xml as a string.

member.summary: Closes the TdXml object and releases all associated resources.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdXml.CreateXmlReader
member.summary: Creates an XmlReader that is used by an application to retrieve the Xml data from a Teradata Database.

remarks.para: When a XmlReader is created by the provider, a request on the existing connection is opened. The Teradata Database only allows 16 open requests per a connection. Therefore, there can only be up to 16 XmlReaders that are opened at the same time. This limit also applies when a combination of LOBs and XmlReaders are concurrently opened.

Because the XmlReader uses provider resources to access the database, it is highly recommended that be called before a XmlReader instance is disposed during garbage collection. This will guarantee that the request that was created will be closed and that other resources will be cleaned up.
The conformance level () has been set to ConformanceLevel.Fragment. The reason for this is that the Teradata Database Xml type supports both Xml documents and fragments.

member.returns: A XmlReader instance is returned.

member.summary: Returns the Xml as a .
member.value: A String that contains the Xml retrieved from the Teradata Database.

remarks.para: The Value property returns the Xml as a string. When this property is accessed for the first time, a request is opened on the connection, the Xml data is retrieved from the Teradata Database, and is stored into a System.String.

There is a limit of 16 requests per a connection that an application can have concurrently opened. If Value is accessed when 16 requests are open, a TdException will get thrown indicating that the maximum limit of streams are open.

A request on a connection will be open when the following occurs:
XmlReader returned from the call to and is open.
or is called to retrieve Xml data when the query has been executed using Deferred mode.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate
member.summary: TdDate is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents a date which is based on the Gregorian Calendar.

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata type Date. Version 1.2 and earlier of the provider map Date to System.DateTime. With the release of version 12.0 of the provider, TdDate is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Date.
The date can range from January 01, 0001 to December 31, 9999.
An application can use the TdDate structure the same way that a System.DateTime is used. TdDate can be used with any version of Teradata supported by the .Net Data Provider for Teradata.

A TdDate can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider --versions earlier than 12.0--, the Connection String Attribute Enable TdDateTime must be set to false. When this is done, a TdDate is returned to an application using the property. The object that is returned from the property remains a System.DateTime.
If the attribute Enable TdDateTime is set to true a TdDate is returned to the application through the TdParameter.Value.

member.seealso: Date And Time Connection String Attribute
Provider Specific Type: Date And Time Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdDate.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdDate is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdDate.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TimeSpan to this instance of TdDate.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdDate is Null a will be returned.

The only component of the TimeSpan object that will be considered is the day component. When this operation is performed, the day component of the TimeSpan is added to the this instance of TdDate. For example, if the date is "2007-10-04" and TimeSpan is "0.02:00:00.00" (0 days, 2 hours) the add operation will result in "2007-10-04".

The number of days will be calculated from the components that were specified when TimeSpan was initialized. Therefore, if a TimeSpan were initialized as new TimeSpan(47, 60, 20) (47 hours, 60 minutes, 20 seconds), the number of days that will be added to TdDate will be 2.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdDate is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalYearToMonth to this instance of TdDate.
member.exception: Unable to add the interval to this instance of TdDate.

remarks.para: If the or this instance is Null a will be returned.
The interval will be added to TdDate. For example, if the date is "2007-10-04" and the interval is "10-03" (10 years, 3 months) the operation will result in "2018-01-04".

member.param: A TdIntervalYearToMonth that will be added to this instance of TdDate.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)

The only component of the TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be considered is the day component. For example, if the date is "2007-10-04" and the interval is "5 03:20:30" (5 days, 3 hours, 20 minutes and 30 seconds) the operation will result in "2007-10-09".

member.param: A TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be added to this instance of TdDate.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate.ToString
member.summary: The TdDate is converted to a String representation of the date.
member.returns: The string representation of TdDate is returned.

remarks.para: The string representation of the data will be in the format: "yyyy-MM-dd".
If the this instance is , a string that contains "Null" will be returned.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: TdDate is converted to the equivalent String using the specified format.
member.param: The DateTime format string that will be used to format the TdDate.
member.returns: A string representation of the date in TdDate.
member.exception: The is invalid.

remarks.para: If the format parameter is null, the string representation of TdDate will be equivalent to the "G" format specifier which is "yyyy-MM-dd".
If the this instance is , a string that contains "Null" will be returned.
The format specifiers that are supported are as follows:

item.description: Short date pattern.
Long date pattern.
The ANSI string representation. For TdDate the format will be an ANSI Date "yyyy-MM-dd". Cultural information is ignored.
Month day pattern
The Teradata literal representation of a Date.
Year month pattern

remarks.para: For more information on format specifiers refer to the in the MSDN documentation.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdDate.ToString(System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Converts a TdDate into the equivalent string representation.
member.param: The culture specific information. This parameter is ignored.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime
member.summary: TdPeriodTime is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents a duration of time that is bound by beginning and ending times.

remarks.para: The Teradata Database introduced the Period type in release 13.00.00.00. Unfortunately, the .Net Framework does not contain a system type that corresponds to the Teradata Period(Time) type. Therefore, the Teradata provider exposes the TdPeriodTime type which enables an application to work with data of type Period(Time).
Similar to , TdPeriodTime supports a scale for the sub-seconds. The scale ranges from 0 to 6 and must be the same for both the beginning and ending bounds.

A period is an anchored duration. It represents a set of contiguous time granules within that duration. In the case of TdPeriodTime, the granularity of the time can range from 10^-6 (.000006 second) to 10^0 (1 second). The representation of a period is both inclusive and exclusive. It is inclusive in that the duration of the period begins from the beginning bound up to, but not including (excluding), the ending bound. For example suppose a TdPeriodTime contains the period of:

The period will include "13:12:21.05" and not "20:43:27.98". It has a duration of 07:31:06.93 (7 hours, 31 minutes, 6 seconds, 980000 microseconds). The time element "15:21:43" is also contained in the period.
The components of a period consists of the following:

list.item: Time Granule This is the minimum representation of time within a period. In the above example, the time granule is 10^-2 (.01 second).
Time Element A Time value that is contained within the period. The time element in TdPeriodTime is specified using a TdTime.
Beginning Bound The lower bound or the start of the period. Within a period, this value represents the "lowest" time element. The beginning bound must be less than the ending bound.
Ending Bound The upper bound or the ending of the period. The Ending Bound is not included in the period. Therefore, No Time Element in the period can be greater or equal to the Ending Bound.
Duration The number of granules in a period. It is represented as an interval/timespan.

remarks.para: A TdPeriodTime can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. The data will be returned to an application using either the TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue or TdParameter.Value property. Retrieving the parameter using TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue, will return the data using the Period structure. When TdParameter.Value is used, the data is returned as a String (this is the corresponding .Net type).

member.seealso: Provider Specific Types: Period Type Overview

This is an invalid period. In this situation, an ArgumentOutOfRangeException will get thrown.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdPeriodTime.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTime is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdPeriodTime.
member.exception: An invalid period will result in this operation.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdPeriodTime is Null a will be returned.

The only component of the object that will be considered is the time component. When this operation is performed, the time component of the TimeSpan is added to the this instance of TdPeriodTime. For example, if the period is "01:00:00, 01:30:00" and TimeSpan is "1.02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the add operation will result in a period of (03:00:00, 03:30:00).

When adding a TimeSpan to a TdPeriodTime it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is
Adding the TimeSpan of "03:00:00" (3 hours) to the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:
Subtracting the TimeSpan of "20:00:00" (20 hours) to the same period will cause the beginning period to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:
Refer to Period Arithmetic for additional information.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTime is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTime.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTime.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdPeriodTime or the is Null a will be returned.

When this operation is performed, the day component of the interval is ignored. Only the hour, minute, and second components are used in this operation. For example, if the period is "01:00:00, 01:30:00" and the interval is "1 02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the add operation will result in a period of (03:00:00, 03:30:00).

When adding an interval to a TdPeriodTime it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is
Adding the interval of "0 03:00:00" (3 hours) to the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:
Adding the interval of "-0 20:00:00" (-20 hours) to the same period will cause the beginning period to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be added to the period.

The only component of the object that will be considered is the time component. When this operation is performed, the time component of the TimeSpan is subtracted from this instance of TdPeriodTime. For example, if the period is "05:00:00, 06:30:00" and TimeSpan is "1.02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the subtract operation will result in a period of (03:00:00, 04:30:00).

When subtracting a TimeSpan from a TdPeriodTime it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is
Subtracting the TimeSpan of "20:00:00" (20 hours) from the period will cause the beginning bound to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:
Subtracting the TimeSpan of "-3:00:00" (-3 hours) from the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime.Compare(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime)
member.summary: Compares two instances of TdPeriodTime structures and returns a value indicating whether is greater than, less than or equal to .
member.returns: The result of the comparison is returned as an integer.

remarks.para: The beginning and ending bounds of the two period operands are used in the comparison. The integer returned when the bounds of the left is compared to right operand indicates the following:

description.para: left.Begin < right.Begin OR (left.Begin == right.Begin AND left.End < right.End)
left.Begin > right.Begin OR (left.Begin == right.Begin AND left.End > right.End)

remarks.pre: left.Begin > right.Begin OR (left.Begin == right.Begin AND left.End > right.End)
remarks.para: The value returned is true if the is greater than the , false otherwise.

item.description: and are not and is greater than .

description.para: is less than or equal to .

remarks.para: Comparison operators always returns false if one of the operands is Null. Therefore, you must not assume that the reverse condition is true. For example you cannot assume that the left operand is less than or equal to the right operand if the GreaterThan operator returns false.

remarks.para: The value returned is true if the is greater than or equal to the , false otherwise.

item.description: and are not and is greater than or equal to .

remarks.para: Comparison operators always returns false if one of the operands is Null. Therefore, you must not assume that the reverse condition is true. For example you cannot assume that the left operand is less than the right operand if GreaterThanOrEqual operator returns false.

member.summary: Compares two TdPeriodTime structures to determine whether the operand is less than or equal to the operand.
member.returns: A boolean is returned that indicates the result of the comparison.

remarks.para: In order to perform this comparison the beginning and ending bounds of the left and right operands are compared against each other. The left is equal to or less than the right if the following is true:
remarks.pre: ((left.Begin < right.Begin) OR (left.Begin == right.Begin AND left.End <= right.End))
remarks.para: The value returned is true if the is less than or equal to the , false otherwise.

item.description: and are not and is less than or equal to .

remarks.para: Comparison operators always returns false if one of the operands is Null. Therefore, you must not assume that the reverse condition is true. For example you cannot assume that the left operand is greater than the right operand if the LessThanOrEqual operator returns false.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime.op_Equality(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime)
member.summary: Compares two TdPeriodTime structures to determine whether the is equal to the operand.
member.returns: A boolean is returned that indicates the result of the comparison.

remarks.para: The beginning and ending bounds between the left and right operands are compared to determine whether the two periods are equal. The two periods are equal if the following is true:
The value returned is true if the is equal to the , false otherwise.

Unlike comparison operators, Equality operators do not always return false when left and right operands are Null. Therefore the reverse condition can be considered true. TdTime implementation is very similar to the class in this regard.

The format specifier and the cultural information only affects the string representation of the beginning and ending bounds of the period. Neither parameter affects the format of the parameter. That is, the delimiter (comma) used to separate the beginning and ending bounds, and the parentheses cannot be changed.
If the format parameter is null, the string representation of TdPeriodTime will be equivalent to the "G" format specifier which is

description.para: The ANSI representation of the period: (HH:mm:ss.ffffff, HH:mm:ss.ffffff).
The Teradata database's literal representation of the period: PERIOD'(HH:mm:ss.ffffff, HH:mm:ss.ffffff)'.

member.summary: The specified string is converted into an equivalent TdPeriodTime.

member.returns: A TdPeriodTime is returned that is equivalent to the Period contained in the value string.
member.exception: Value is a null reference.

remarks.para: A period will have the following string representation:

The period must be surrounded by parentheses. Both the Beginning and Ending bounds can optionally be surrounded by single quotes (" ' "). The exception to this is when the Teradata literal string representation of period is specified. The comma (" , ") is used as the delimeter between the Begin and End bounds.
Refer to for valid formats for TdPeriodTime.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime.IntervalTimeSpan
member.summary: Gets the span of time in the period as a TimeSpan.
member.returns: The TimeSpan value that contains the span of time starting from the beginning bound to, but not including, the ending bound.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan that is returned represents the number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds of the duration.

members.member:
Calculates the span of time between the starting and ending bounds and returns the result in a TdIntervalDayToSecond structure.
The TdIntervalDayToSecond value that contains the difference in hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds between the period ending bound and the period starting bound. > This instance of TdPeriodTime is null.
The difference between the ending bound and the starting bound is calculated. The number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds are calculated and returned in a TdIntervalDayToSecond type.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime.LeftDiff(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTime)
member.summary: The period whose beginning and ending bounds are defined as the beginning bound of the operand and the beginning bound of the operand when the operands overlap.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTime is returned that includes the portion of the left operand that exists before the beginning of the right operand when the operands overlap.

remarks.para: A is returned under the following scenarios:

list.item: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bound of the left operand is less than the beginning bound of the right operand.
Either the left or right operand is null.

remarks.para: In the following examples the left and right operand are defined as (bL, eL) and (bR, eR), respectively.

item.description: Ldiff = (bL, bR)
Ldiff = (bL, bR)

description.para: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bound of the right operand is greater than the beginning bound of the left.
The beginning bound of the right operand is greater than the beginning bound of the left.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bounds of both operands are equal. A period cannot be created whose beginning and ending bounds are equal.

Either the left or right operand is null.

remarks.para: In the following examples the left and right operands are defined as (bL, eL) and (bR, eR), respectively.

item.description: Rdiff = (eL, eR)
Rdiff = (eL, eR)

description.para: The left operand's ending bound is greater than the ending bound of the right operand.
The left operand's ending bound is greater than the ending bound of the right operand.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The ending bounds are equal. In other words, a period cannot be defined whose starting and ending bounds are equal.

Normalize = (bR, eR)

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp
member.summary: TdPeriodTimestamp is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents a duration of time that is bound by beginning and ending timestamps.

remarks.para: The Teradata Database introduced the Period type in release 13.00.00.00. Unfortunately, the .Net Framework does not contain a system type that corresponds to the Teradata Period(Timestamp) type. Therefore, the Teradata provider exposes the TdPeriodTimestamp type which enables an application to work with data of type Period(Timestamp).
Similar to , TdPeriodTimestamp supports a scale for the sub-seconds. The scale ranges from 0 to 6 and must be the same for both the beginning and ending bounds.

A period is an anchored duration. It represents a set of contiguous time granules within that duration. In the case of TdPeriodTimestamp, the granularity of the time can range from 10^-6 (.000006 second) to 10^0 (1 second). The representation of a period is both inclusive and exclusive. It is inclusive in that the duration of the period begins from the beginning bound up to, but not including (excluding), the ending bound. For example suppose a TdPeriodTimestamp contains the period of:

The period will include "2008-10-31 13:12:21.05" and not "2008-12-01 20:43:27.98". It has a duration of 32.07:31:06.93 (32 days, 7 hours, 31 minutes, 6 seconds, 980000 microseconds). The time element "2008-11-30 15:21:43" is included in the period.
The components of a period consists of the following:

list.item: Time Granule This is the minimum representation of time within a period. In the above example, the time granule is 10^-2 (.01 second).
Time Element A Time value that is contained within the period. The time element in TdPeriodTimestamp is specified using a TdTimestamp.
Beginning Bound The lower bound or the start of the period. Within a period, this value represents the "lowest" time element. The beginning bound must be less than the ending bound.
Ending Bound The upper bound or the ending of the period. The Ending Bound is not included in the period. Therefore, No Time Element in the period can be greater or equal to the Ending Bound.
Duration The number of granules in a period. It is represented as an interval/timespan.

remarks.para: A TdPeriodTimestamp can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. The data will be returned to an application using either the TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue or TdParameter.Value property. Retrieving the parameter using TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue, will return the data using the Period structure. When TdParameter.Value is used, the data is returned as a String (this is the corresponding .Net type).

member.seealso: Provider Specific Types: Period Type Overview

member.summary: Gets a Null TdPeriodTimestamp instance.
member.value: Returns a TdPeriodTimestamp instance that represents a Null value.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.#ctor(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp)
member.summary: A period is created from two TdTimestamp structures that represent the lower and upper bounds of the duration.
member.exception: Either the begin or end date is null.
Ending bound is less than the beginning bound.
member.param: The starting time of the period.
The ending time of the period.

remarks.para: The will be set to the maximum scale between the and parameters.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.#ctor(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp,System.Byte)
member.summary: A period is created from two TdTimestamp structures that represent the lower and upper bounds of the duration.
member.exception: Either the begin or end date is null.
Ending bound is less than the beginning bound or the scale is not in the valid range.
The scale specified will cause either the beginning or ending bound to be truncated.
member.param: The starting time of the period.
The ending time of the period.

remarks.para: The cannot cause the truncation of either the beginning or ending bounds. The reason for this is that if the scale of the beginning or ending bounds is truncated it is possible the the resulting period will be invalid. For example, suppose a period is to be created with a scale of 1 from the two timestamp: "1010-11-23 17:10:33.0121", and "1010-11-23 17:10:33.0999". If the scale of both these timestamp are readjusted to 1, both the beginning and ending bounds will be "1010-11-23 17:10:33.0121". The beginning and ending bounds of a period cannot be equal.

member.returns: A TdPeriodDate is returned.
member.remarks: The time components of the beginning and ending bound will be truncated when TdPeriodTimestamp is converted into a TdPeriodDate.

remarks.para: If the ending bound is set to the UNTIL_CHANGED value for TdPeriodTimestamp, the ending bound of the result will be set to the UNTIL_CHANGED value for the resulting . The UTC offset component is also set to the offset of the local machine, and the Scale of the period is set to 6.
When the TdPeriodTimestamp is converted into a TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone, the UTC offset is set to the offset of the local machine.

member.summary: Compares this instance against to determine whether they are equal.
member.returns: true is returned if the two TdPeriodTimestamps are equal, false otherwise.

The boolean that is returned indicates the following conditions:
false will be returned if:

list.item: This instance or is .
This instance is not equal to .
is not of type TdPeriodTimestamp or null.

remarks.para: true will be returned if:

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestamp is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.exception: The result could not be represented as a TdPeriodTimestamp.
The TdPeriodTimestamp beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para:
If this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp is Null a
will be returned.
The TimeSpan will be added to both the beginning and ending bounds.

The number of days will be calculated from the components that were specified when TimeSpan was initialized. Therefore, if a TimeSpan were initialized as new TimeSpan(47, 60, 20) (47 hours, 60 minutes, 20 seconds), what will be added to the TdPeriodTimestamp will be 2 days, 20 seconds.
Refer to Period Arithmetic for more information.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestamp is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
The TdPeriodTimestamp beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para: If or this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp is Null a will be returned.

The TdIntervalDayToSecond will be added to both the beginning and ending bounds of the period. If the scale between this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp and the are different, the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdPeriodTimestamp.

For example, if the period is "2007-10-04 12:50:56.2123", "2007-11-01 13:23:54.4435") and the interval is "200 20:40:50.654321" (200 days, 20 hours, 40 minutes, 50 seconds and 654321 microseconds), the add operation will result in a period of ("2008-04-22 09:31:46.8666", "2008-05-20 10:04:45.0978").

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be added to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestamp is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalYearToMonth to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.exception: Unable to add the interval to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
The TdPeriodTimestamp beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para: If the or this instance is Null a will be returned.

The interval will be added to a TdPeriodTimestamp. For example, if the TdPeriodTimestamp is ("2007-10-04 12:50:56", "2007-11-01 13:23:54") and the interval is "5-10" (5 years, 10 months) the operation will result in "2013-08-04 12:50:56", "2013-09-01 13:23:54").

member.param: A TdIntervalYearToMonth that will be added to this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.Subtract(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be subtracted from this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be subtracted.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestamp is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan subtracted from this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.exception: The result could not be represented as a TdPeriodTimestamp.
The TdPeriodTimestamp beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para:
If this instance of TdPeriodTimestamp is Null a
will be returned.

The number of days will be calculated from the components that were specified when TimeSpan was initialized. Therefore, if a TimeSpan was initialized as new TimeSpan(47, 60, 20) (47 hours, 60 minutes, 20 seconds), the number of days that will be subtracted from TdPeriodTimestamp will be 2 days and 20 seconds.
Refer to Period Arithmetic for more information.

The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdPeriodTimestamp.

For example, if the period is "2007-10-04 12:50:56.2123", "2007-11-01 13:23:54.4435") and the interval is "200 20:40:50.654321" (200 days, 20 hours, 40 minutes, 50 seconds and 654321 microseconds), the subtract operation will result in a period of ("2007-03-17 16:10:05.5579", "2007-04-14 16:43:03.7891").

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.Subtract(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth)
member.summary: Subtracts the specified from this instance of .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.Compare(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp)
member.summary: Compares two instances of TdPeriodTimestamp structures and returns a value indicating whether is greater than, less than or equal to .
member.returns: The result of the comparison is returned as an integer.

remarks.para: The beginning and ending bounds of the two period operands are used in the comparison. The integer returned when the bounds of the left is compared to right operand indicates the following:

description.para: left.Begin < right.Begin OR (left.Begin == right.Begin AND left.End < right.End)
left.Begin > right.Begin OR (left.Begin == right.Begin AND left.End > right.End)

member.summary: Compares two TdPeriodTimestamp structures to determine whether the operand is greater than the operand.

remarks.para: Comparison operators always returns false if one of the operands is Null. Therefore, you must not assume that the reverse condition is true. For example you cannot assume that the left operand is less than or equal to the right operand if the GreaterThan operator returns false.

remarks.para: A period will have the following string representation:

The period must be surrounded by parentheses. Both the Beginning and Ending bounds can optionally be surrounded by single quotes (" ' "). The exception to this is when the Teradata literal string representation of period is specified. The comma (" , ") is used as the delimeter between the Begin and End timestamps.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.IntervalTimeSpan
member.summary: Gets the span of time in the period.
member.returns: The TimeSpan value that contains the span of time starting from the beginning bound to, but not including, the ending bound.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan that is returned represents the number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds of the duration.

members.member:
Calculates the span of time between the starting and ending bounds and returns the result in a TdIntervalDayToSecond structure.
The TdIntervalDayToSecond value that contains the difference in hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds between the period ending bound and the period starting bound. > This instance of TdPeriodTimestamp is null. The period exceeds the or .
The difference between the ending bound and the starting bound is calculated. The number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds are calculated and returned as a TdIntervalDayToSecond.

Calculates the span of time between the starting and ending bounds and returns the result in a TdIntervalYearToMonth structure.
The TdIntervalYearToMonth value that contains the difference in years and months between the period ending bound and the period starting bound. > This instance of TdPeriodTimestamp is null.
The difference between the ending bound and the starting bound are calculated. Only the years and months are used in the calculation.
The TdIntervalYearToMonth supports only years and months. The days are discarded during the difference calculation.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp.LeftDiff(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp)
member.summary: The period whose beginning and ending bounds are defined as the beginning bound of the operand and the beginning bound of the operand when the operands overlap.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestamp is returned that includes the portion of the left operand that exists before the beginning of the right operand when the operands overlap.

remarks.para: A is returned under the following scenarios:

list.item: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bound of the left operand is greater than the beginning bound of the right operand.
Either the left or right operand is null.

remarks.para: In the following examples the left and right operand are defined as (bL, eL) and (bR, eR), respectively.

item.description: Ldiff = (bL, bR)
Ldiff = (bL, bR)

description.para: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bound of the right operand is greater than the beginning bound of the left.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bounds of both operands are equal. A period cannot be created whose beginning and ending bounds are equal.

The ending bound of the left operand is greater or equal to the ending bound of the right.
Either the left or right operand is null.

item.description: Rdiff = (eL, eR)
Rdiff = (eL, eR)

description.para: The left operand's ending bound is greater than the ending bound of the right operand.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The ending bounds are equal. In other words, a period cannot be defined whose starting and ending bounds are equal.

Normalize = (bR, eR)

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone
member.summary: TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents a duration of time that is bound by beginning and ending timestamps that have a time zone.

remarks.para: The Teradata Database introduced the Period type in release 13.00.00.00. Unfortunately, the .Net Framework does not contain a system type that corresponds to the Teradata Period(TimestampWithTimeZone) type. Therefore, the Teradata provider exposes the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone type which enables an application to work with data of type Period(TimestampWithTimeZone).
Similar to , TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone supports a scale for the sub-seconds and a UTC offset. The scale ranges from 0 to 6 and must be the same for both the beginning and ending bounds.

A period is an anchored duration. It represents a set of contiguous time granules within that duration. In the case of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone, the granularity of the time can range from 10^-6 (.000006 second) to 10^0 (1 second). The representation of a period is both inclusive and exclusive. It is inclusive in that the duration of the period begins from the beginning bound up to, but not including (excluding), the ending bound. For example suppose a TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone contains the period of:

The duration will include "2008-10-31 13:12:21.05+08:00" and not "2008-12-01 20:43:27.98+08:00". It has a duration of 32.07:31:06.93 (32 days, 7 hours, 31 minutes, 6 seconds, 980000 microseconds). The time element "2008-11-30 15:21:43+08:00" is included in the period.
The components of a period consists of the following:

list.item: Time Granule This is the minimum representation of time within a period. In the above example, the time granule is 10^-2 (.01 second).
Time Element A Time value that is contained within the period. The time element in TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is specified using a TdTimestampWithTimeZone.
Beginning Bound The lower bound or the start of the period. Within a period, this value represents the "lowest" time element. The beginning bound must be less than the ending bound.
Ending Bound The upper bound or the ending of the period. The Ending Bound is not included in the period. Therefore, No Time Element in the period can be greater or equal to the Ending Bound.
Duration The number of granules in a period. It is represented as an interval/timespan.

remarks.para: The UTC Offset of the beginning and ending bounds do not have to be the same. However, the UTC representation of the beginning bound must be less than the UTC representation of the ending bound.

A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. The data will be returned to an application using either the TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue or TdParameter.Value property. Retrieving the parameter using TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue, will return the data using the Period structure. When TdParameter.Value is used, the data is returned as a String (this is the corresponding .Net type).

member.seealso: Provider Specific Types: Period Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
member.exception: The result could not be represented as a TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
The TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is Null a will be returned.
The TimeSpan will be added to both the beginning and ending bounds.

The number of days will be calculated from the components that were specified when TimeSpan was initialized. Therefore, if a TimeSpan were initialized as new TimeSpan(47, 60, 20) (47 hours, 60 minutes, 20 seconds), what will be added to the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone will be 2 days, 20 seconds.
Refer to Period Arithmetic for additional information.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

remarks.para: If or this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is Null a will be returned.

The TdIntervalDayToSecond will be added to both the beginning and ending bounds of the period. If the scale between this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone and the are different, the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

The TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para: If the or this instance is Null a will be returned.

The interval will be added to a TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone. For example, if the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is ("2007-10-04 12:50:56-08:00", "2007-11-01 13:23:54-08:00") and the interval is "5-10" (5 years, 10 months) the operation will result in "2013-08-04 12:50:56-08:00", "2013-09-01 13:23:54-08:00").

The number of days will be calculated from the components that were specified when TimeSpan was initialized. Therefore, if a TimeSpan was initialized as new TimeSpan(47, 60, 20) (47 hours, 60 minutes, 20 seconds), the number of days that will be subtracted from TdPeriodDate will be 2 days and 20 seconds.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.Subtract(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Subtracts the specified from this instance of .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned that is the result of subtracting the TdIntervalDayToSecond from this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
member.exception: Unable to subtract the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond from this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

remarks.para: If or this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is Null a will be returned.

The TdIntervalDayToSecond will be subtracted from both the beginning and ending bounds of the period. If the scale between this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone and the is different, the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

For example, if the period is "2007-10-04 12:50:56.2123-08:00", "2007-11-01 13:23:54.4435-08:00") and the interval is "200 20:40:50.654321" (200 days, 20 hours, 40 minutes, 50 seconds and 654321 microseconds), the subtract operation will result in a period of ("2007-03-17 16:10:05.5579-08:00", "2007-04-14 16:43:03.7891-08:00").

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be subtracted from this instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.op_Subtraction(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Subtracts the specified from a .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned that is the result of subtracting the TdIntervalDayToSecond from a TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
member.exception: Unable to subtract the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond from a TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
The TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone beginning bound is greater or equal to the ending bound of the period.

remarks.para: If or is Null a will be returned.

The TdIntervalDayToSecond will be subtracted from both the beginning and ending bounds of the period. If the scale between and the is different, the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

For example, if the period is "2007-10-04 12:50:56.2123-08:00", "2007-11-01 13:23:54.4435-08:00") and the interval is "200 20:40:50.654321" (200 days, 20 hours, 40 minutes, 50 seconds and 654321 microseconds), the subtract operation will result in a period of ("2007-03-17 16:10:05.5579-08:00", "2007-04-14 16:43:03.7891-08:00").

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be subtracted from the TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

The format specifier is only used when formatting the string representation of the beginning and ending bounds of the period. It will not affect the format of the period.
If the format parameter is null, the string representation of TdPeriodTimestamp will be equivalent to the "G" format specifier which is
The following format specifiers are supported by TdPeriodTimestamp:

description.para: The ANSI representation of the period: (yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ, yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ).
The Teradata database's literal representation of the period: PERIOD'(yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ, yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ)'.

Value does not contain a valid representation of a period.

remarks.para: A period will have the following string representation:

The period must be surrounded by parentheses. Both the Beginning and Ending bounds can optionally be surrounded by single quotes (" ' "). The exception to this is when the Teradata literal string representation of period is specified. The comma (" , ") is used as the delimeter between the Begin and End timestamps.
Refer to for valid formats for TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.

A period will have the following string representation:
(Beginning Bound, Ending Bound)

The period must be surrounded by parentheses. Both the Beginning and Ending bounds can optionally be surrounded by single quotes (" ' "). The exception to this is when the Teradata literal string representation of period is specified. The comma (" , ") is used as the delimeter between the Begin and End timestamps.
Refer to for valid formats for TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.
If is null or String.Empty, a false is returned and the parameter is set to .
If the conversion fails the result parameter will be set to TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.MinValue.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.IntervalTimeSpan
member.summary: Gets the span of time in the period.
member.returns: The TimeSpan value that contains the span of time starting from the beginning bound to, but not including, the ending bound.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan that is returned represents the number of days, hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds of the duration.

members.member:
Calculates the span of time between the starting and ending bounds and returns the result in a TdIntervalDayToSecond structure.
The TdIntervalDayToSecond value that contains the difference in hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds between the period ending bound and the period starting bound. > This instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is null. The period exceeds the or .
The difference between the ending bound and the starting bound is calculated. The number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds are calculated and returned as a TdIntervalDayToSecond.

Calculates the span of time between the starting and ending bounds and returns the result in a TdIntervalYearToMonth structure.
The TdIntervalYearToMonth value that contains the difference in years and months between the period ending bound and the period starting bound. > This instance of TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is null.
The difference between the ending bound and the starting bound are calculated. Only the years and months are used in the calculation.
The TdIntervalYearToMonth supports only years and months. The days are discarded during the difference calculation.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.LeftDiff(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone)
member.summary: The period whose beginning and ending bounds are defined as the beginning bound of the operand and the beginning bound of the operand when the operands overlap.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned that includes the portion of the left operand that exists before the beginning of the right operand when the operands overlap.

remarks.para: It is required that the UTC Offset of both the and operand be the same.
A is returned under the following scenarios:

list.item: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bound of the left operand is less than the beginning bound of the right operand.
Either the left or right operand is null.

remarks.para: In the following examples the left and right operand are defined as (bL, eL) and (bR, eR), respectively.

item.description: Ldiff = (bL, bR)
Ldiff = (bL, bR)

description.para: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bound of the right operand is greater than the beginning bound of the left.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The beginning bounds of both operands are equal. A period cannot be created whose beginning and ending bounds are equal.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.RightDiff(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone)
member.summary: The period that contains the portion from the ending bound of the operand to the ending bound of the when the operands overlap.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned that contains the period that begins from the end of the left operand to the end of the right when the operands overlap.

remarks.para: It is required that the UTC Offset of both the and operand be the same.
A is returned under the following scenarios:

list.item: The left and right operands do not overlap.
The ending bound of the left operand is greater or equal to the ending bound of the right.
Either the left or right operand is null.

remarks.para: In the following examples the left and right operands are defined as (bL, eL) and (bR, eR), respectively.

item.description: Rdiff = (eL, eR)
Rdiff = (eL, eR)

description.para: The left operand's ending bound is greater than the ending bound of the right operand.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The left and right operands do not overlap.
The ending bounds are equal. In other words, a period cannot be defined whose starting and ending bounds are equal.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone.Normalize(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone,Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone)
member.summary: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone that contains a period that encompasses both periods of the left and right operands. The beginning bound is defined as the minimum of left and right beginning bounds, and the ending bound is defined as the maximum of the left and right ending bounds. The operands must either meet or overlap.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimestampWithTimeZone is returned whose period includes both operands.

remarks.para: It is required that the UTC Offset of both the and operand be the same.
A is returned under the following scenarios:

list.item: The left and right operands do not overlap.
Either the left or right operand is null.

remarks.para: In the following examples the left and right operands are defined as (bL, eL) and (bR, eR), respectively.

item.description: Normalize = (bL, eR)
Normalize = (bR, eL)
Normalize = (bL, eL)
Normalize = (bR, eR)
Normalize = (bL, eR)

description.para: The periods are equal. In this scenario, the period specified as the left parameter will be returned. It will be adjusted to the maximum scale between the left and right parameters.

description.para: There is an intersection between the operands; therfore, the left does not precede the right.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone
member.summary: TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents a duration of time that is bound by beginning and ending times that have a time zone.

remarks.para: The Teradata Database introduced the Period type in release 13.00.00.00. Unfortunately, the .Net Framework does not contain a system type that corresponds to the Teradata Period(TimeWithTimeZone) type. Therefore, the Teradata provider exposes the TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone type which enables an application to work with data of type Period(TimeWithTimeZone).
Similar to , TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone supports a scale for the sub-seconds and a UTC Offset. The scale ranges from 0 to 6 and must be the same for both the beginning and ending bounds.

A period is an anchored duration. It represents a set of contiguous time granules within that duration. In the case of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone, the granularity of the time can range from 10^-6 (.000006 second) to 10^0 (1 second). The representation of a period is both inclusive and exclusive. It is inclusive in that the duration of the period begins from the beginning bound up to, but not including (excluding), the ending bound. For example suppose a TdPeriodTime contains the period of:

The duration will include "13:12:21.05+08:00" and not "20:43:27.98+08:00". It has a duration of 07:31:06.93 (7 hours, 31 minutes, 6 seconds, 980000 microseconds). The time element "15:21:43+08:00" is also included in the period.
The components of a period consists of the following:

list.item: Time Granule This is the minimum representation of time within a period. In the above example, the time granule is 10^-2 (.01 second).
Time Element A Time value that is contained within the period. The time element in TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is specified using a TdTimeWithTimeZone.
Beginning Bound The lower bound or the start of the period. Within a period, this value represents the "lowest" time element. The beginning bound must be less than the ending bound.
Ending Bound The upper bound or the ending of the period. The Ending Bound is not included in the period. Therefore, No Time Element in the period can be greater or equal to the Ending Bound.
Duration The number of granules in a period. It is represented as an interval/timespan.

remarks.para: The UTC Offset of the beginning and ending bounds do not have to be the same. However, the UTC representation of the beginning bound must be less than the UTC representation of the ending bound.

A TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. The data will be returned to an application using either the TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue or TdParameter.Value property. Retrieving the parameter using TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue, will return the data using the Period structure. When TdParameter.Value is used, the data is returned as a String (this is the corresponding .Net type).

member.seealso: Provider Specific Types: Period Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
member.exception: An invalid period will result in this operation.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is Null a will be returned.

The only component of the object that will be considered is the time component. When this operation is performed, the time component of the TimeSpan is added to the this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone. For example, if the period is "01:00:00-08:00, 01:30:00-08:00" and TimeSpan is "1.02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the add operation will result in a period of (03:00:00-08:00, 03:30:00-08:00).

When adding a TimeSpan to a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is
Adding the TimeSpan of "03:00:00" (3 hours) to the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:
Subtracting the TimeSpan of "20:00:00" (20 hours) to the same period will cause the beginning period to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:
Refer to Period Arithmetic for additional information.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone or the is Null a will be returned.

When this operation is performed, the day component of the interval is ignored. Only the hour, minute, and second components are used in this operation. For example, if the period is "01:00:00-08:00, 01:30:00-08:00" and the interval is "1 02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the add operation will result in a period of (03:00:00-08:00, 03:30:00-08:00).

When adding an interval to a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is
Adding the interval of "0 03:00:00" (3 hours) to the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:
Adding the interval of "-0 20:00:00" (-20 hours) to the same period will cause the beginning period to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be added to the period.

member.exception: Unable to add the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond to a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.

remarks.para: If or the is Null a will be returned.

When this operation is performed, the day component of the interval is ignored. Only the hour, minute, and second components are used in this operation. For example, if the period is "01:00:00-08:00, 01:30:00-08:00" and the interval is "1 02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the add operation will result in a period of (03:00:00-08:00, 03:30:00-08:00).

When adding an interval to a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is
Adding the interval of "0 03:00:00" (3 hours) to the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:
Adding the interval of "-0 20:00:00" (-20 hours) to the same period will cause the beginning period to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be added to the period.

member.remarks: Refer to and Period Arithmetic for additional information.

member.summary: Subtracts the specified from a .

member.exception: Unable to subtract the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond from a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.

remarks.para: If or the is Null a will be returned.

When this operation is performed, the day component of the interval is ignored. Only the hour, minute, and second components are used in this operation. For example, if the period is "05:00:00-08:00, 06:30:00-08:00" and the interval is "1 02:00:00.00" (1 day, 2 hours) the subtract operation will result in a period of "03:00:00-08:00, 04:30:00-08:00".

When subtracting a interval from a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone it is possible that the ending bound will roll into the next 24 hours, or the beginning bound will roll into the previous 24 hours. For example, suppose the period is:
Subtracting the interval of "0 20:00:00" (20 hours) from the period will cause the beginning bound to roll back into the previous 24 hours which results in the invalid period:
Subtracting the interval of "-0 03:00:00" (-3 hours) from the period will cause the ending bound to roll into the next 24 hours which will result in the invalid period:

member.param: The TdIntervalDayToSecond interval will be subtracted from a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is converted to the equivalent String using the specified format.
member.param: The DateTimeWithTimeZone format string that will be used to format the TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
member.returns: A string representation of the Period.

remarks.para: When a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is converted to a string, both the beginning and ending bounds will be included in the returning string. The format of the string will be:

The format specifier and the cultural information only affects the string representation of the beginning and ending bounds of the period. Neither parameter affects the format of the parameter. That is, the delimiter (comma) used to separate the beginning and ending bounds, and the parentheses cannot be changed.
If the format parameter is null, the string representation of TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone will be equivalent to the "G" format specifier which is
The following format specifiers are supported by TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone:

description.para: The ANSI representation of the period: (HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ, HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ).
The Teradata database's literal representation of the period: PERIOD'(HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ, HH:mm:ss.ffffffZ)'.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: The specified string is converted into an equivalent TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
member.param: The string that is to be converted into a TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
member.returns: A TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone is returned that is equivalent to the Period contained in the value string.
member.exception: Value is a null reference.
Value does not contain a valid representation of a period.

remarks.para: A period will have the following string representation:
(Beginning Bound, Ending Bound)

The period must be surrounded by parentheses. Both the Beginning and Ending bounds can optionally be surrounded by single quotes (" ' "). The exception to this is when the Teradata literal string representation of period is specified. The comma (" , ") is used as the delimeter between the Begin and End bounds.
Refer to for valid formats for TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.

A period will have the following string representation:
(Beginning Bounds, Ending Bounds)

The period must be surrounded by parentheses. Both the Beginning and Ending bounds can optionally be surrounded by single quotes (" ' "). The exception to this is when the Teradata literal string representation of period is specified. The comma (" , ") is used as the delimeter between the Begin and End bounds.
Refer to for valid formats for TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.
If is null or String.Empty, a false is returned and the parameter is set to .
If the conversion fails the result parameter will be set to TdPeriodTimeWithTimeZone.MinValue.
