member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from time components specified as integers while precision and scale components are specified as bytes.

remarks.para: The number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds are constructed into a TdIntervalHourToSecond. The microseconds parameter represents 10 ^-6 seconds and the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^-6 (.000001) to create a fractional number of seconds. The supplied scale is used to used to truncate any fractional seconds at the position indicated by the scale.

For example, a microseconds value of 12345678 and a scale of 6 will be divided by 10^-6 and truncated at the 6th position resulting in a value of .123456. A microseconds value of 123 and a scale of 6 will result in a value of .000123.

All values are converted into a TdIntervalHourToSecond to determine if the or the values are exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting hours component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.

For example a constructor for TdIntervalHourToSecond(44, 6001, 10, 90, 2, 6) requests 44 hours, 6001 minutes, 10 seconds and 90 microseconds with a precision of 2 and a scale of 6. The resulting TdIntervalHourToSecond literal value of '144:01:10.000090' contains an hours value which cannot be represented in 2 digits. Therefore an exception is generated, even though the MinValue and the MaxValue values have not been exceeded.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalHourToSecond. For instance, an hour value of 20, a minutes value of -4900, a seconds value of 30, a microsecond value of 123456, a second precision of 4 and a scale of 6 will result in a TdIntervalHourToSecond interval value of -'61:40:30.123456'.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalHourToSecond value less than or greater than .
The precision or scale parameters are outside the minimum or maximum range of values.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of hours.
member.overloads: Initializes a new instance of TdIntervalHourToSecond.
member.param: Number of significant digits of the hour.
The number of decimal places for the second.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from the time components specified as integers.

remarks.para: The number of hours, minutes, seconds and microseconds are constructed into a TdIntervalHourToSecond and evaluated against and . The microseconds parameter represents 10 ^-6 seconds and the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^-6 (.000001) to create a fractional number of seconds. The is then calculated from the number of fractional seconds required. The is calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval hour component.

For example 100 hours, 75 minutes, 300 seconds and 455666 microseconds is first converted into a TdIntervalHourToSecond and evaluated against MinValue and MaxValue. The TdIntervalMinuteToSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond value of '101:20:00.455666'. Precision is calculated to be a value of 3 representing three significant digits of 101 hours. The scale is calculated to be 6 from the number of decimal places right of the seconds interval which equals the value.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalHourToSecond. For instance, an hour value of 20, a minutes value of -4900, a seconds value of 30, and a microsecond value of 123456 will result in a TdIntervalHourToSecond interval value of -'61:40:30.123456' with a calculated precision of 2 and a calculated scale of 6.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalHourToSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a .

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a TdIntervalHourToSecond and evaluated against and . The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval hour component and the is calculated from the number of decimal places required to represent the fractional seconds.

After conversion of the TimeSpan value into TdIntervalHourToSecond, any fractional seconds will be truncated according the the value of 6 decimal places. For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 368601234567 results in a value of 0 days, 10 hours, 14 minutes and 20.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalHourToSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalHourToSecond value of '10:14:20.123456'. The .1234567 seconds value is truncated by one significant digit. Precision is calculated to be a value of 2 representing two significant digits in the hour.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalHourToSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created using a specifying the precision and the scale as bytes.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a TdIntervalHourToSecond and evaluated against and . If the values are not exceeded but the resulting hours component exceeds the supplied parameter value, an exception is generated.
After conversion of the TimeSpan value into a TdIntervalHourToSecond, any fractional seconds will be truncated according the the supplied parameter .

For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 368601234567 results in a value of 0 days, 10 hours, 14 minutes and 20.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalHourToSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalHourToSecond value of '10:14:20.123456'. The .1234567 seconds value will truncated by the supplied parameter . The supplied parameter must be a value greater than or equal to 2 and less than or equal to to eliminate exceptions due to truncation of the minutes component.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalHourToSecond value less than or greater than .
The precision or scale parameters are outside the minimum or maximum range of values.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of hours.
member.param: The number of significant digits of the hour.
The number of decimal places for the second.

member.returns: A TdIntervalHourToSecond is returned that is equivalent to the TdIntervalHourToSecond contained in the input string.
member.exception: cannot be converted into a TdIntervalHourToSecond interval.
is a null reference.
The resultant operation returns a value greater than the or less than the .

remarks.para: This method supports the following string formats:

description.para: Teradata literal format. This string may be used in generating SQL against the Teradata database.

remarks.para: Below is the description of each format item.

item.description: Optional - . Defaults as space character (+).
Required number of hours (one to four digits in length).
Required number of minutes from 00 - 59.
Required number of seconds from 00 - 59.
Optionally the number of fractional seconds (0 to 6 digits in length).

remarks.para: Cultural settings are not supported.

While parsing the the will be set to the number of digits contained within the hour component. The will be set to the number of digits in the fractional seconds component (digits that are to the right of the decimal point).
For example a of "10:25:40.1234" will contain a precision of 2 and a scale of 4.

member.overloads: The specified string is converted into an equivalent TdIntervalHourToSecond interval.
member.param: A string to be converted into a TdIntervalHourToSecond.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.Hours
member.summary: The number of interval hours is returned. The return value ranges from -9999 to 9999.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][hours]:mm:ss.ffffff. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The hours component represents hours, the mm component minutes, the ss seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Hours property is the hours component.
A negative interval will return all properties (hours, minutes, seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.

member.exception: This property is not available when this instance is .

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.Minutes
member.summary: The number of interval minutes is returned. The return value ranges from -59 to 59.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][hours]:mm:ss.ffffff. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The hours component represents hours, the mm component minutes, the ss seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Minutes property is the mm component.
A negative interval will return all properties (hours, minutes, seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.

member.exception: This property is not available when this instance is .

member.summary: The number of interval seconds is returned. The return value ranges from -59 to 59.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][hours]:mm:ss.ffffff. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The hours component represents hours, the mm component minutes, the ss seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Seconds property is the ss component.
A negative interval will return all properties (hours, minutes, seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.

member.exception: This property is not available when this instance is .

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalHourToSecond.Microseconds
member.summary: The number of interval microseconds is returned. The return value ranges from -999999 to 999999.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][hours]:mm:ss.ffffff. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The hours component represents hours, the mm component minutes, the ss seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Microseconds property is the ffffff component. The .ffffff component is optional.
A negative interval will return all properties (hours, minutes, seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.

member.summary: The decimal fractional seconds are returned. The return value ranges from -999999 to 999999.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][hours]:[mm]:[ss].[ffffff]. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The hours represents hours, the mm minutes, the ss seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Microseconds property is the ffffff component.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinute
member.summary: represents an interval of time defining a duration in minutes. The minute precision is configurable.

remarks.para: TdIntervalMinute is a .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific type, designed to support a Teradata Database Interval Minute data type.
The TdIntervalMinute supports the Teradata Interval Minute (precision) data type where precision indicates the number of digits in the minutes (from 1 - 4).
The interval value must be specified in the following format :
[sign][minutes]
Below is the description of each format item.

item.description: Optional - . Defaults as space character (+).
Required number of minutes (one to four digits in length).

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata Database Interval Minute data type. The .NET Data Provider for Teradata Version 13.0 version and prior versions map Interval Minute to System.String. With version 13.1 of the provider, TdIntervalMinute is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Interval Minute.
The range of values for each TdIntervalMinute precision is as follows:

TdIntervalMinute also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.
A TdIntervalMinute structure allows arithmetic, comparision and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdIntervalMinute may also be specified as an in, out, or in/out parameter to a stored procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider (release 13.0 and prior), a Connection String Attribute EnableTdIntervals has been added. When the EnableTdIntervals attribute is true, will return the data as the provider specific type of TdIntervalMinute. When EnableTdIntervals is false, TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue will return the data as a .NET Framework Library data type of .

The will also return the .NET Framework Library data type of System.String when EnableTdIntervals is false to maintain backward compatibility. The TdParameter.Value will return a .NET Framework data type of when EnableTdIntervals is true.
For more information on the Teradata Interval Minute data type please see the Teradata Database SQL Reference - 'Data Types and Literals'.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a TdIntervalSecond, modify the interval, and then update the table.

member.seealso: Provider Specific Type: Interval Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinute.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a time component specified as an integer while precision is specified as a byte.

remarks.para: The number of minutes is converted into a TdIntervalMinute and validated to determine if the or the values have been exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting minutes component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.

For example a constructor for TdIntervalMinute(444, 2) requests 444 minutes with a precision of 2. The resulting minutes value cannot be represented in 2 digits, therefore an exception is generated, even though the MinValue and the MaxValue values have not been exceeded.
Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time.

member.exception: The minutes parameter specifies a TdIntervalMinute value less than or greater than .
The precision parameter is outside the or range of values."/>.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of minutes.
member.overloads: Initializes a new instance of TdIntervalMinute.
member.param: Number of significant digits of the day.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinute.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from time components specified as integers.

remarks.para: The number of minutes is constructed into a TdIntervalMinute and evaluated against and . The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval minute component.
For example, 99 minutes is first constructed into a TdIntervalMinute. Precision is calculated to be a value of 2 representing two significant digits in the minutes.
Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time.

member.exception: The minutes parameter specifies a TdIntervalMinute value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinute.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a .

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a TdIntervalMinute and evaluated against and . The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval minute component.

After conversion of the TimeSpan value into a TdIntervalMinute, any seconds or microseconds will be truncated. For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 2400401234567 results in a value of 40 hours, 0 minutes and 40.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalMinute literal representation results in a TdIntervalMinute value of '4000'. The 40.1234567 seconds value is truncated. Precision is calculated to be a value of 4 representing four significant digits in the minute.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalMinute value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinute.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created using a specifying the minute precision as a byte.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a TdIntervalMinute"/> and evaluated against and . If the values are not exceeded but the resulting minutes component exceeds the supplied parameter value, an exception is generated.

After conversion of the TimeSpan value into a TdIntervalMinute, any seconds or microseconds will be truncated. For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 2400401234567 results in a value of 40 hours, 0 minutes and 40.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalMinute literal representation results in a TdIntervalMinute value of '4000'. The 40.1234567 seconds value is truncated.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalMinute value less than or greater than .
The precision parameter is outside the or range of values."/>.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of minutes.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond
member.summary: represents an interval of time defining a duration in minutes, seconds and fractional seconds. The minute precision and second scale are configurable.

remarks.para: TdIntervalMinuteToSecond is a .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific type, designed to support a Teradata Database Interval Minute To Second data type.

The TdIntervalMinuteToSecond supports the Teradata Interval Minute (precision) To Second (scale) data type where precision indicates the number of digits in the minutes (from 1 - 4) and scale indicates the fractional precision for the values of seconds. The scale may range from 0 to 6.
The interval value must be specified in the following format :
[sign][minutes]:[ss].[ffffff]
Below is the description of each format item.

item.description: Optional - . Defaults as space character (+).
Required number of minutes (one to four digits in length).
Required number of seconds from 00 - 59.
Optionally the number of fractional seconds (0 to 6 digits in length).

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata Database Interval Minute To Second data type. The .NET Data Provider for Teradata Version 13.0 version and prior versions map Interval Minute To Second to System.String. With version 13.1 of the provider, TdIntervalMinuteToSecond is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Interval Minute To Second.
The range of values for the TdIntervalMinuteToSecond containing a minute precision of 1 is as follows:

The range of values for minute precision values of 2,3 and 4 all follow the same pattern. For completeness, the following chart displays the range of values for a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond with a minute precision of 4.

TdIntervalMinuteToSecond also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.
A TdIntervalMinuteToSecond structure allows arithmetic, comparision and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdIntervalMinuteToSecond may also be specified as an in, out, or in/out parameter to a stored procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider (release 13.0 and prior), a Connection String Attribute EnableTdIntervals has been added. When the EnableTdIntervals is true, will return the data as the provider specific type of TdIntervalMinuteToSecond. When EnableTdIntervals is false, TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue will return the data as a .NET Framework Library data type of .

The will also return the .NET Framework Library data type of System.String when EnableTdIntervals is false to maintain backward compatibility. The TdParameter.Value will return a .NET Framework data type of when EnableTdIntervals is true.
For more information on the Teradata Interval Minute To Second data type please see the Teradata Database SQL Reference - 'Data Types and Literals'.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond, modify the interval, and then update the table.

member.seealso: Provider Specific Type: Interval Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from time components specified as integers while precision and scale components are specified as bytes.

remarks.para: The number of minutes, seconds and microseconds are converted into a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond. The microseconds parameter represents 10 ^-6 seconds and the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^-6 (.000001) to create a fractional number of seconds. The supplied scale is used to used to truncate any fractional seconds at the position indicated by the scale.

For example, a microseconds value of 12345678 and a scale of 6 will be divided by 10^-6 and truncated at the 6th position resulting in a value of .123456. A microseconds value of 123 and a scale of 6 will result in a value of .000123.

All values are converted into a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond to determine if the or the values are exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting minutes component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.

For example a constructor for TdIntervalMinuteToSecond(444, 6001, 90, 2, 6) requests 444 minutes, 2 seconds, 90 microseconds with a precision of 2 and a scale of 6. The resulting TdIntervalMinuteToSecond literal value of '544:01.000090' contains a minutes value which cannot be represented in 2 digits. Therefore an exception is generated, even though the MinValue and the MaxValue values have not been exceeded.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalMinuteToSecond. For instance, a minute value of 20, a second value of -4900, a microsecond value of 30, a second precision of 4 and a scale of 6 will result in a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond interval value of -'61:40.000030'.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from the time components specified as integers.

remarks.para: The number of minutes, seconds and microseconds are constructed into a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond and evaluated against and . The microseconds parameter represents 10 ^-6 seconds and the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^-6 (.000001) to create a fractional number of seconds. The is then calculated from the number of fractional seconds required. The is calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval minute component.

For example 75 minutes, 300 seconds and 455666 microseconds is first converted into a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond and evaluated against MinValue and MaxValue. The TdIntervalMinuteToSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond value of '80:00.455666'. Precision is calculated to be a value of 2 representing two significant digits of 80 minutes. The scale is calculated to be 6 from the number of decimal places right of the seconds interval which equals the value.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalMinuteToSecond. For instance, a minute value of 20, a second value of -4900, and a microsecond value of 30 will result in a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond interval value of -'61:40.000030' with a calculated precision of 2 and a calculated scale of 6.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a .

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a and evaluated against and . The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval minute component and the is calculated from the number of decimal places required to represent the fractional seconds.

After conversion of the TimeSpan value into TdIntervalMinuteToSecond, any fractional seconds will be truncated according the the value of 6 decimal places. For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 8601234567 results in a value of 0 days, 0 hours, 14 minutes and 20.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalMinuteToSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond value of '14:20.123456'. The .1234567 seconds value is truncated by one significant digit. Precision is calculated to be a value of 2 representing two significant digits in the minute.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created using a specifying the precision and the scale as bytes.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond and evaluated against and . If the values are not exceeded but the resulting minutes component exceeds the supplied parameter value, an exception is generated.
After conversion of the TimeSpan value into a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond, any fractional seconds will be truncated according the the supplied parameter .

For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 8601234567 results in a value of 0 days, 0 hours, 14 minutes and 20.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalMinuteToSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalMinuteToSecond value of '14:20.123456'. The .1234567 seconds value will truncated by the supplied parameter . The supplied parameter must be a value greater than or equal to 2 and less than or equal to to eliminate exceptions due to truncation of the minutes component.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.InternalTimespan
member.summary: Return the internal TimeSpan representing the interval.
member.remarks: The internal timespan is used in calculating arithmetic operations and in storing day-time intervals.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.ObjectId
member.summary: Gets the instance object identifier.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.DecimalFractionalSecond
member.summary: The decimal fractional seconds are returned. The return value ranges from -999999 to 999999.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][minutes]:[ss].[ffffff]. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The minutes represents minutes, the ss seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Microseconds property is the ffffff component.
A negative interval will return all properties (minutes, seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.
This property is used in ToString to display the interval as a decimal fractional second.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.IsNegative
member.summary: Indicate if the interval is negative.
member.remarks: Timespan.ticks will indicate a negative interval. Other values (days, hours, minutes, milliseconds) may be 0 and the interval may still be negative.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMinuteToSecond.InternalAccessor
member.summary: Accessor to the internal storage for this interval.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMonth
member.summary: represents an interval of time defining a duration in months. The month precision is configurable from 1 - 4 significant digits.

remarks.para: TdIntervalMonth is a .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific type, designed to support a Teradata Database Interval Month data type.
The TdIntervalMonth supports the Teradata Interval Month (precision) data type where precision indicates the number of digits in the months (from 1 - 4).
The interval value must be specified in the following format :
[sign][months]

item.description: Optional - or space character.
Required number of months (one to four digits in length).

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata Database Interval Month data type. The .NET Data Provider for Teradata Version 13.0 version and prior versions map Interval Month to System.String. With version 13.1 of the provider, TdIntervalMonth is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Interval Month.
The range of values for each TdInterval precision is as follows:

TdIntervalMonth also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.
A TdIntervalMonth structure allows arithmetic, comparision and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdIntervalMonth may also be specified as an in, out, or in/out parameter to a stored procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider (release 13.0 and prior), a Connection String Attribute EnableTdIntervals has been added. When the EnableTdIntervals attribute is true, will return the data as the provider specific type of TdIntervalMonth. When EnableTdIntervals is false, TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue will return the data as a .NET Framework Library data type of .
The will return the .NET Framework Library data type of System.String whether EnableTdIntervals is true or false.
For more information on the Teradata Interval Month data type please see the Teradata Database SQL Reference - 'Data Types and Literals'.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a TdIntervalMonth, modify the interval, and then update the table.

member.seealso: Provider Specific Type: Interval Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMonth.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a month date component specified as an integer.

remarks.para: The number of months is evaluated against and and to determine if the values are exceeded. The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval month component.
For example, a month value of 99 results in a precision of 2 representing 2 significant digits in the month.
A year value of 10020 exceeds the the maximum value of '9999-11' generating an exception.
Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of duration.

member.exception: The months parameter specifies a TdIntervalMonth value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMonth.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a month date component specified as an integer with precision specified as a byte.

remarks.para: The allowable values of precision are from 1 - 4.

The number of months is evaluated against and and to determine if the values are exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting months component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.
For example, a month value of 99 and a precision of 1 will generate an exception. The interval component cannot be represented in 1 significant digit, thus resulting in an invalid TdIntervalMonth.
Negative may be supplied to represent negative duration of time.

member.exception: The precision parameter is less than the or greater than the range of values.
The months parameter specifies a TdIntervalMonth value less than or greater than .
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of months.
member.overloads: Initializes a new instance of TdIntervalMonth.
member.param: Number of significant digits of the month.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMonth.op_Explicit(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalMonth)~Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYear
member.summary: Converts a to .
member.returns: A TdIntervalYear.

remarks.para: Truncation will occur while converting TdIntervalMonth if the months interval component is not divisible by 12 with a remainder of 0.
For example a value of TdIntervalMonth of 49 will result in a TdIntervalYear value of '4' resulting in the truncation of 1 month (49/12 = 4 with a remainder of 1).

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond
member.summary: represents an interval of time defining a duration in seconds and fractional seconds. The second precision and scale are configurable.

remarks.para: TdIntervalSecond is a .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific type, designed to support a Teradata Database Interval Second data type.

The TdIntervalSecond supports the Teradata Interval Second (precision, scale) data type where precision indicates the number of digits in the seconds (from 1 - 4) and scale indicates the fractional precision for the values of seconds. The scale may range from 0 to 6.
The interval value must be specified in the following format :
[sign][seconds].[ffffff]
Below is the description of each format item.

item.description: Optional - . Defaults as space character (+).
Required number of seconds (one to four digits in length).
Optionally the number of fractional seconds (0 to 6 digits in length).

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata Database Interval Second data type. The .NET Data Provider for Teradata Version 13.0 version and prior versions map Interval Second to System.String. With version 13.1 of the provider, TdIntervalSecond is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Interval Second.
The range of values for the TdIntervalSecond containing a second precision of 1 is as follows:

The range of values for second precision values of 2,3 and 4 all follow the same pattern. For completeness, the following chart displays the range of values for a TdIntervalSecond with a second precision of 4.

TdIntervalSecond also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.
A TdIntervalSecond structure allows arithmetic, comparision and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdIntervalSecond may also be specified as an in, out, or in/out parameter to a stored procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider (release 13.0 and prior), a Connection String Attribute EnableTdIntervals has been added. When the EnableTdIntervals attribute is true, will return the data as the provider specific type of TdIntervalSecond. When EnableTdIntervals is false, TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue will return the data as a .NET Framework Library data type of .

The will also return the .NET Framework Library data type of System.String when EnableTdIntervals is false to maintain backward compatibility. The TdParameter.Value will return a .NET Framework data type of when EnableTdIntervals is true.
For more information on the Teradata Interval Second data type please see the Teradata Database SQL Reference - 'Data Types and Literals'.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a TdIntervalSecond, modify the interval, and then update the table.

member.seealso: Provider Specific Type: Interval Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from time components specified as integers while precision and scale components are specified as bytes.

remarks.para: The number of seconds and microseconds are constructed into a TdIntervalSecond. The microseconds parameter represents 10 ^-6 seconds and the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^-6 (.000001) to create a fractional number of seconds. The supplied scale is used to used to truncate any fractional seconds at the position indicated by the scale.

For example, a microseconds value of 12345678 and a scale of 6 will be divided by 10^-6 and truncated at the 6th position resulting in a value of .123456. A microseconds value of 123 and a scale of 6 will result in a value of .000123.

All values are constructed into a TdIntervalSecond to determine if the or the values are exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting seconds component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.

For example a constructor for TdIntervalSecond(444, 90, 2, 6) requests 444 seconds and 90 microseconds with a precision of 2 and a scale of 6. The resulting TdIntervalSecond literal value of '444.000090' contains a seconds value which cannot be represented in 2 digits. Therefore an exception is generated, even though the MinValue and the MaxValue values have not been exceeded.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalSecond. For instance, a second value of -4900, a microsecond value of 30, a second precision of 4 and a scale of 6 will result in a TdIntervalSecond interval value of -'4899.000070'.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalSecond value less than or greater than .
The precision or scale parameters are outside the minimum or maximum range of values.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of seconds.
member.overloads: Initializes a new instance of TdIntervalSecond.
member.param: Number of significant digits of the second.
The number of decimal places for the second.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from the time components specified as integers.

remarks.para: The number of seconds is constructed into a TdIntervalSecond and evaluated against and . The is set to zero for this constructor. The is calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval second component.

For example 300 seconds is first converted into a TdIntervalSecond and evaluated against MinValue and MaxValue. Precision is calculated to be a value of 3 representing three significant digits in 300 seconds. The scale is set to zero.
Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from the time components specified as integers.

remarks.para: The number of seconds and microseconds are constructed into a TdIntervalSecond and evaluated against and . The microseconds parameter represents 10 ^-6 seconds and the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^-6 (.000001) to create a fractional number of seconds. The is then calculated from the number of fractional seconds required. The is calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval second component.

For example 300 seconds and 455666 microseconds is first constructed into a TdIntervalSecond and evaluated against MinValue and MaxValue. The TdIntervalSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalSecond value of '300.455666'. Precision is calculated to be a value of 3 representing three significant digits in 300 seconds. The scale is calculated to be 6 from the number of decimal places right of the seconds interval which equals the value.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalSecond. For instance, a second value of -4900, and a microsecond value of 30 will result in a TdIntervalSecond interval value of -'4899.000070' with a calculated precision of 4 and a calculated scale of 6.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a .

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a and evaluated against and . The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval second component and the is calculated from the number of decimal places required to represent the fractional seconds.

After conversion of the TimeSpan value into TdIntervalSecond, any fractional seconds will be truncated according the the value of 6 decimal places. For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 8601234567 results in a value of 0 days, 0 hours, 14 minutes and 20.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalSecond value of '860.123456'. The .1234567 seconds value is truncated by one significant digit. Precision is calculated to be a value of 3 representing three significant digits in the second.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalSecond value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond.#ctor(System.TimeSpan,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created using a specifying the precision and the scale as bytes.

remarks.para: The TimeSpan value is converted into a TdIntervalSecond and evaluated against and . If the values are not exceeded but the resulting seconds component exceeds the supplied parameter value, an exception is generated.
After conversion of the TimeSpan value into a TdIntervalSecond, any fractional seconds will be truncated according the the supplied parameter .

For example, a TimeSpan value created with a value of 8601234567 results in a value of 0 days, 0 hours, 14 minutes and 20.1234567 seconds. The TdIntervalSecond literal representation results in a TdIntervalSecond value of '860.123456'. The .1234567 seconds value will truncated by the supplied parameter . The supplied parameter must be a value greater than or equal to 3 and less than or equal to to eliminate exceptions due to truncation of the seconds component.

member.exception: The timespan parameter specifies a TdIntervalSecond value less than or greater than .
The precision or scale parameters are outside the minimum or maximum range of values.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of seconds.
member.param: Number of significant digits of the second.
The number of decimal places for the second.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalSecond.Seconds
member.summary: The number of interval seconds is returned. The return value ranges from -9999 to 9999.

remarks.para: A is represented as [-][seconds].[ffffff]. The minus sign is optional and represents a negative interval of time. The seconds component represents seconds and the ffffff fractional seconds. The value of the Seconds property is the seconds component.
A negative interval will return all properties (seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.

member.exception: This property is not available when this instance is .

A negative interval will return all properties (seconds and fractional seconds) as negative values.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYear
member.summary: represents an interval of time defining a duration in years. The year precision is configurable from 1 - 4 significant digits.

remarks.para: TdIntervalYear is a .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific type, designed to support a Teradata Database Interval Year data type.
The TdIntervalYear supports the Teradata Interval Year (precision) data type where precision indicates the number of digits in the years (from 1 - 4).
The interval value must be specified in the following format :
[sign][years]
Below is the description of each format item.

item.description: Optional - or space character.
Required number of years (one to four digits in length).

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata Database Interval Year data type. The .NET Data Provider for Teradata Version 13.0 version and prior versions map Interval Year to System.String. With version 13.1 of the provider, TdIntervalYear is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Interval Year.
The range of values for each TdInterval precision is as follows:

TdIntervalYear also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.
A TdIntervalYear structure allows arithmetic, comparision and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdIntervalYear may also be specified as an in, out, or in/out parameter to a stored procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider (release 13.0 and prior), a Connection String Attribute EnableTdIntervals has been added. When the EnableTdIntervals attribute is true, will return the data as the provider specific type of TdIntervalYear. When EnableTdIntervals is false, TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue will return the data as a .NET Framework Library data type of .
The will return the .NET Framework Library data type of System.String whether EnableTdIntervals is true or false.
For more information on the Teradata Interval Year data type please see the Teradata Database SQL Reference - 'Data Types and Literals'.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a TdIntervalYear, modify the interval, and then update the table.

member.seealso: Provider Specific Type: Interval Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYear.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a year date component specified as an integer.

remarks.para: The number of years is evaluated against and and to determine if the values are exceeded. The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval year component.
For example, a year value of 99 results in a precision of 2 representing 2 significant digits in the year.
A year value of 10020 exceeds the the maximum value of '9999-11' generating an exception.
Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of duration.

member.exception: The years parameter specifies a TdIntervalYear value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYear.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from a year date component specified as an integer with precision specified as a byte.

remarks.para: The allowable values of precision are from 1 to 4.

The number of years is evaluated against and and to determine if the values are exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting years component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.
For example, a year value of 99 and a precision of 1 will generate an exception. The interval component cannot be represented in 1 significant digit, thus resulting in an invalid TdIntervalYear.
Negative may be supplied to represent negative duration of time.

member.exception: The years parameter specifies a TdIntervalYear value less than or greater than .
The precision parameter is less than the or greater than the range of values.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of years.
member.overloads: Initializes a new instance of TdIntervalYear.
member.param: Number of significant digits of the year.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth
member.summary: represents an interval of time defining a duration in years and/or months. The year precision is configurable from 1 - 4 significant digits.

remarks.para: TdIntervalYearToMonth is a .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific type, designed to support a Teradata Database Interval Year To Month data type.
The TdIntervalYearToMonth supports the Teradata Interval Year (precision) To Month data type where precision indicates the number of digits in the years (from 1 - 4).
The interval value must be specified in the following format :
[sign][years]-[mm]
Below is the description of each format item.

item.description: Optional - or space character.
Required number of years (one to four digits in length).
Required 2 digits representing the months from 00 - 11.

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata Database Interval Year To Month data type. The .NET Data Provider for Teradata Version 13.0 version and prior versions map Interval Year To Month to System.String. With version 13.1 of the provider, TdIntervalYearToMonth is available to retrieve and manipulate data of type Interval Year To Month.
The range of values for each TdInterval precision is as follows:

TdIntervalYearToMonth also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.
A TdIntervalYearToMonth structure allows arithmetic, comparision and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdIntervalYearToMonth may also be specified as an in, out, or in/out parameter to a stored procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider (release 13.0 and prior), a Connection String Attribute EnableTdIntervals has been added. When the EnableTdIntervals attribute is true, will return the data as the provider specific type of TdIntervalYearToMonth. When EnableTdIntervals is false, TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue will return the data as a .NET Framework Library data type of .
The will return the .NET Framework Library data type of System.String whether EnableTdIntervals is true or false.
For more information on the Teradata Interval Year To Month data type please see the Teradata Database SQL Reference - 'Data Types and Literals'.

example.para: The following example shows how to retrieve a TdIntervalYearToMonth, modify the interval, and then update the table.

member.seealso: Provider Specific Type: Interval Type Overview

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of is created from year and month date components specified as integers.

remarks.para: The number of years and months are converted into months first and then evaluated against and . The is then calculated from the number of digits contained within the interval year component.

For example, a year value of 99 and a month value of 45 results in a value in total months of 1233 months. The TdIntervalYearToMonth literal representation results in a TdIntervalYearToMonth value of 102 years and 9 months within the range of less than or equal to MaxValue and greater than or equal to the MinValue. Precision is calculated to be a value of 3 representing 3 significant digits in the year.

A year value of 200 and a month value of 118,000 results in a value in total months of 120,400 months. The TdIntervalYearToMonth literal representation results in a TdIntervalYearToMonth value of 10,033 years and 4 months exceeding the maximum value of '9999-11'.

Negative constructor parameters may be supplied to represent negative durations of time. Mixed positive and negative constructor parameters are added together that result in a negative or positive TdIntervalYearToMonth. For instance, a year value of 200 and a month value of -4900 will result in a TdIntervalYearToMonth interval value of -'208-04' with a calculated precision value of 3.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalYearToMonth value less than or greater than .

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte)
member.summary: An instance of is created from year and month date components specified as integers with precision specified as a byte.

remarks.para: The allowable values of precision are from 1 - 4.

All values are converted into months and the values are added to determine if the or the values are exceeded. If the values are not exceeded but the resulting years component exceeds the supplied value, an exception is generated.

For example a year value of 200, a month value of 12,006 and a precision of 3 results in a value in total months of 12,206 months. The TdIntervalYearToMonth literal representation results in a TdIntervalYearToMonth value of 1,200 years and 6 months. The interval component cannot be represented in 3 significant digits, therefore resulting in an invalid TdIntervalYearToMonth.

member.exception: The parameters specify a TdIntervalYearToMonth value less than or greater than .
The precision parameter is outside the or range of values.
The precision parameter is not large enough to represent the number of years.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime
member.summary: TdTime is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents the time of day.

remarks.para: The .Net Framework does not have a system type that directly corresponds to the Teradata type Time. The .Net Data Provider for Teradata Version 1.2 and earlier versions map Time to System.TimeSpan. With the release of version 12.0 of the provider, TdTime is available to retrieve and manipulate data of Teradata type Time.

Similar to the Teradata Database's Time type, the TdTime also supports a scale for the sub-seconds --this is referred to as . The scale can range from 0 to 6. The microseconds and scale are specified in the constructor. An example of a time is "17:22:10.0329". This time has a of "32900", and a of "4".
When a TdTime is parsed (see ) the scale of the resulting TdTime will be set to the actual scale of the fractional component of the time.
When data of a column that is a Time is retrieved as a TdTime, it's scale will be set to the scale of the column.
The TdTime structure allows arithmetic, comparison, and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdTime value can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider --versions earlier than 12.0--, the Connection String Attribute Enable TdDateTime must be set to false. When this is done, a TdTime is returned to an application using the property. The object that is returned from the property remains a System.TimeSpan object.
If the attribute Enable TdDateTime is set to true a TdTime is returned to the application through the TdParameter.Value.

example.para: The following example retrieves data of two TIME columns from Teradata, modifies the data, and then updates the record with the new data contained in TdTime.

member.seealso: Date And Time Connection String Attribute
Provider Specific Type: Date And Time Overview

member.remarks: The largest possible value of TdTime is equivalent to 23:59:59.

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime.MinValue
member.summary: The smallest possible value of TdTime. This field is read-only.
member.remarks: The smallest possible value of TdTime is equivalent to 00:00:00.

member.remarks: Conceptually it is the constructor for Null TdTime instances.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of TdTime is created from the time components specified as integers.
member.param: The hour of the specified time. Valid values are 0-23.
The minutes of the specified time. Valid value are 0-59.
The seconds of the specified time. Valid values are 0-59.

remarks.para: The scale will default to the minimum scale of 0 which corresponds to the Teradata "TIME" type.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of TdTime is create from the time components specfied as integers.
member.param: The hour of the specified time. Valid values are 0-23.
The minutes of the specified time. Valid value are 0-59.
The seconds of the specified time. Valid values are 0-59.
The number of microseconds of the specified time.
member.exception: One of the time components is out of range.

remarks.para: A microsecond is 10^-6 of a second (.000001).
The scale will default to the scale of the parameter.

When the time is created, the microsecond parameter is divided by 10^6 --this corresponds to a microsecond. This becomes the fractional portion of the time. For example, if "23" is specified as the , the fraction portion of the time is ".000023", and the scale will be 6. A microsecond of "2000" will become ".002000", and the scale will be 3.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of TdTime is created from the time components specfied as integers.
member.param: The hour of the specified time. Valid values are 0-23.
The minutes of the specified time. Valid value are 0-59.
The seconds of the specified time. Valid values are 0-59.
The number of microseconds of the specified time.
The scale of the time. Valid values are 0-6.
member.exception: One of the time components is out of range.

remarks.para: A microsecond is 10^-6 of a second (.000001).

When the time is created, the microsecond parameter will first be divided by 10^6 --this corresponds to a microsecond. Then this fractional portion of the timestamp will be truncated at the position specified by the scale. For example, if "231" were passed in as the microsecond and 6 as the scale, the fraction component will be set to ".000231". However, if the microsecond is 23145 and the scale is 3, the fractional component will be ".023"

item.description: and are not and is less than or equal to .

remarks.para: Comparison operators always returns false if one of the operands is Null. Therefore, you must not assume that the reverse condition is true. For example you cannot assume that the left operand is greater than the right operand if the "<=" operator returns false.
Refer to for further information on this inequality operator.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdTime.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdTime is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdTime.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdTime is Null a will be returned.

The TimeSpan object can contain data about the number of hours, minutes, seconds, and sub-seconds. If the time rolls into the next or previous day, the result will only contain the time component. For example, adding 2 hours to "23:54:00-08:00" will result in "01:54:00-08:00".

If the scale between this instance of TdTime and the parameter are different the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the time. For example, the addition operation
results in a TdTime value of "12:50:56.2123".

A can have a scale up to 7. A TdTime has a maximum scale of 6. When performing an arithmetic operation, only the first 6 digits to the right of the decimal point of the TimeSpan operand will be considered. The 7th digit will be ignored.

The TdIntervalDayToSecond interval will be added to this instance of TdTime.

The TdIntervalDayToSecond interval may contain data about the number of days, hours, minutes, seconds, and sub-seconds. The days will be discarded during all calculations. If the time rolls into the next or previous day, the result will only contain the time component. For example, adding 2 hours to "23:54:00" will result in a TdTime value of "01:54:00".

If the scale between this instance of TdTime and the parameter are different, the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdTime. For example, if the TdIntervalDayToSecond value of "222 10:25:40.61234" (222 days, 10 hours, 25 minutes and 40.61234 seconds) is added to the TdTime value of "12:50:56.2123" the operation will result in a TdTime value of "23:16:36.8246".

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTime.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: The specified string is converted into an equivalent TdTime.
member.param: The string that is to be converted into a TdTime.
member.returns: A TdTime is returned that is equivalent to the time contained in the value string.
member.exception: Value is a null reference.
Value does not contain a valid representation of a time.

remarks.para: The string is parsed using the culture information contained in the specified object.

If the time contains sub-seconds, the separator that must be used in the string is a decimal point ("."). For example, in the string "10:21:22.2321" the sub-seconds is separated from the number of seconds using a decimal point.

When the is parsed the will be set to the number of digits in the sub-seconds component (digits that are to the right of the decimal point). Therefore, a TdTime of "12:32:11.0000" will have a Scale of 4, and "23:43:22.121000" will have a scale of 6.

An attempt is made to avoid throwing a FormatException. Any unrecognized characters in the string will be ignored. An exception to this is the case when the number of digits to the right of the decimal point exceed the maximum scale of 6. If the number of digits exceed the maximum scale, a FormatException will get thrown. Trailing zeroes are ignored.

However, when a custom culture is used it is possible that the Parse will fail. A times string that contains custom culture specific date elements is very difficult to parse. The string may not match any of the implicit patterns that are used to parse a string.
If the contains the string "NULL" a will be returned.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp
member.summary: TdTimestamp is a .Net Data Provider for Teradata specific type that represents a timestamp that is based on the Gregorian Calendar.

remarks.para: The .Net Framework system type directly corresponds to the Teradata type Timestamp. Therefore, the .Net Data Provider for Teradata Version 1.2 and earlier versions map Timestamp to System.DateTime.

The Provider Specific Types for Date And Time that are supported in the release of version 12.0 of the provider makes available custom types that directly correspond to Teradata Date And Time Types. Although System.DateTime maps directly to Teradata Timestamp, a provider specific type will be provided to applications that will also map to Timestamp called TdTimestamp.

The main difference between TdTimestamp and System.DateTime is that TdTimestamp contains a scale that is associated with the sub-second component of the timestamp. This directly corresponds with the Teradata Timestamp data type.

TdTimestamp also supports . This is a very important feature. An application is no longer required to call before invoking the corresponding TdDataReader "Get" method. This will improve overall performance.

The can range from 0 to 6. This is similar to Teradata Database's Timestamp type. The sub-seconds is specified as a . The Microsecond and Scale are specified in the constructor. An example of a timestamp is "2001-12-10 15:31:11.0021". This timestamp has a Microsecond of "2100", and a Scale of "4".
When a TdTimestamp is parsed (see ) the scale of the resulting TdTimestamp will be set to the actual scale of the fractional component of the timestamp.
When data of a column that is a Timestamp is retrieved as a TdTimestamp, it's scale will be set to the scale of the column.
The TdTimestamp structure allows arithmetic, comparison, and conversion operations to be performed.

A TdTimestamp value can also be specified as an In, Out, or InOut parameter to a Stored Procedure. In order to maintain backward compatibility with previous versions of the provider --versions earlier than 12.0--, the Connection String Attribute Enable TdDateTime must be set to false. When this is done, a TdTimestamp is returned to an application using the property. The object that is returned from the property remains a System.DateTime.
If the attribute Enable TdDateTime is set to true a TdTimestamp is returned to the application through the TdParameter.Value.

example.para: The following example calls a stored procedure that returns a timestamp as an output parameter. The procedure that is called has the signature

para.code: TimeEnrolledInClass(IN studentId VARCHAR(9), IN classId VARCHAR(9), OUT timeEnrolled TIMESTAMP)

member.seealso: Date And Time Connection String Attribute
Provider Specific Type: Date And Time Overview

The month of the specified date. Valid values are 01-12.

member.exception: One of the date components is out of range.

remarks.para: The Time components will be filled in with "00:00:00".

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: TdTimestamp is created from the date and time components specified as integers.
member.param: The year of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0001-9999.
The month of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 01-12.
The day of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 1-31.
The hour of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-23.
The minute of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-59.
The second of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-59.
member.exception: A date or time component is not in the valid range.

remarks.para: The scale will default to the minimum scale of 0.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of TdTimestamp is created from the date and time components specified as integers.
member.param: The year of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0001-9999.
The month of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 01-12.
The day of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 1-31.
The hour of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-23.
The minute of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-59.
The second of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-59.
member.exception: A date or time component is not in the valid range.

remarks.para: A microsecond is 10^-6 of a second (.000001).
The scale will default to the scale of the microsecond.

When the TdTimestamp is created, the microsecond parameter will be divided by 10^6 to create the fractional component of TdTimestamp. For example, if 231 were passed in as the microsecond, the fractional component will be set to ".000231", and the scale will be 6.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: An instance of TdTimestamp is created from the date and time components specified as integers.
member.param: The year of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0001-9999.
The month of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 01-12.
The day of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 1-31.
The hour of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-23.
The minute of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-59.
The second of the specified timestamp. Valid values are 0-59.
The scale of the timestamp. Valid values are 0-6.
member.exception: A date or time component is not in the valid range.

remarks.para: A microsecond is 10^-6 of a second (.000001).

When the TdTimestamp is created, the microsecond parameter will first be divided by 10^6 --this corresponds to a microsecond. Then this fractional portion of the timestamp will be truncated at the position specified by the scale. For example, if "231" were passed in as the microsecond and 6 as the scale, the fraction component will be set to ".000231". However, if the microsecond is 23145 and the scale is 3, the fractional component will be ".023"

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.#ctor(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of TdTimestamp using the specified DateTime structure.
member.param: The DateTime structure that will be used to build the date and time components.

remarks.para: The DateTimeKind property will be ignored when the time components of the TdTimestamp structure is initialized with the time components from the DateTime structure. Therefore, adjustments will not be made for local time.

The DateTime structure can contain a fraction of a second that is up to seven digits. Teradata can only support a fraction that is 6 digits. Therefore, if the DateTime structure contains a fraction of a second that contains more than 6 digits, it will be truncated after the sixth position.
The scale will default to the number of digits contained in the fractional component of the DateTime structure. The maximum value it will be set to is 6.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.#ctor(System.DateTime,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of TdTimestamp using the specified DateTime structure.
member.param: The DateTime structure that will be used to build the date and time components.
The scale of the timestamp. The scale can range from 0 - 6.
member.exception: The scale is not between 0 and 6.

remarks.para: The DateTimeKind property will be ignored when the time components of the TdTimestamp structure is initialized with the time components from the DateTime structure. Therefore, adjustments will not be made for local time.
If the fraction contained in the DateTime structure contains more digits than what has been specified in the , the fraction will be truncated to match the scale.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.op_Explicit(System.DateTime)~Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp
member.summary: A DateTime value is converted into a TdTimestamp.
member.param: The DateTime value that is to be converted.
member.returns: A TdTimestamp is returned that is equivalent to the DateTime value.
member.remarks: If the sub-second component of the Datetime contains more than 6 digits, the sub-seconds will be truncated when the DateTime is converted into a TdDate. For example, when a DateTime value of "2007-10-31 10:12:00.3245431" is converted into a TdTimestamp the sub-second component, ".324531" will be truncated to "324543". The resulting TdTimestamp is "2007-10-31 10:12:00.23453".

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.op_Explicit(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp)~Teradata.Client.Provider.TdPeriodTimestamp
member.summary: Converts a TdTimestamp into a TdPeriodTimestamp.
member.param: The TdTimestamp that is to be converted.
member.returns: a TdPeriodTimestamp is returned that has a beginning bound of and ending bound that is one time granule greater than value.
member.exception: The ending bound could not be created because the is set to

remarks.para: A TdTimestamp can be cast to a TdPeriodTimestamp. The beginning bounds of the period will be , and the ending bound will be the value plus one time granule.
The time granule is dependent upon the scale of the value. For example, if the scale of value is 0 the time granule is 1 second. If the scale is 6 the time granule is 1 microsecond.
The scale of the period will be the same as that of value.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.Add(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: The specified TimeSpan will be added to this instance of TdTimestamp.
member.param: The TimeSpan that will be added.
member.returns: A TdTimestamp is returned that is the result of the TimeSpan added to this instance of TdTimestamp.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TimeSpan to this instance of TdTimestamp.

remarks.para: If this instance of TdTimestamp is Null a will be returned.
The TimeSpan object can contain data about the number of days, hours, minutes, seconds, and fractional seconds.

If the scale between this instance of TdTimestamp and the parameter are different the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the timestamp. For example, the addition operation
results in a TdTimestamp value of "2008-10-10 12:50:56.2123".

A can have a scale up to 7. A TdTimestamp has a maximum scale of 6. When performing an arithmetic operation, only the first 6 digits to the right of the decimal point of the TimeSpan operand will be considered. The 7th digit will be ignored.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalDayToSecond)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdTimestamp is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdTimestamp.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TdIntervalDayToSecond to this instance of TdTimestamp.

remarks.para: If or this instance of TdTimestamp is Null a will be returned.
The TdIntervalDayToSecond interval will be added to this instance of TdTimestamp.

If the scale between this instance of TdTimestamp and the parameter are different, the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the TdTimestamp. For example, if the TdIntervalDayToSecond value of "222 10:25:40.61234" (222 days, 10 hours, 25 minutes and 40.61234 seconds) is added to the TdTimestamp value of "2008-10-10 12:50:56.2123" the operation will result in a TdTimestamp value of "2009-05-20 23:16:36" with 824600 microseconds.

member.param: A TdIntervalDayToSecond that will be added to this instance of TdTimestamp.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.Add(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdIntervalYearToMonth)
member.summary: Adds the specified to this instance of .
member.returns: A TdTimestamp is returned that is the result of adding the TdIntervalYearToMonth to this instance of TdTimestamp.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TdIntervalYearToMonth to this instance of TdTimestamp.

remarks.para: If or this instance of TdTimestamp is Null a will be returned.

The interval will be added to this instance of TdTimestamp. For example, if the TdTimestamp value of "2008-10-10 12:50:56.2123" is added to the TdIntervalYearToMonth value of "10-03" (10 years, 3 months) the operation will result in a TdTimestamp value of "2019-01-10 12:50:56 PM" with 212300 microseconds.

member.param: A TdIntervalYearToMonth that will be added to this instance of TdTimestamp..

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp.op_Addition(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTimestamp,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Adds the specified TimeSpan to a TdTimestamp.

member.returns: A TdTimestamp is returned that is the result of adding the Timespan to TdTimestamp.
member.exception: Unable to add the specified TimeSpan to the the TdTimestamp.
member.remarks:
If is Null a will be returned.
If the scale between the and the parameters are different the arithmetic operation will be performed using the different scales. The result will then be truncated to match the scale of the timestamp. For example, the addition operation
TdTimestamp.Parse("2008-10-10 12:48:53.2123") + TimeSpan.Parse("00:02:03.000099")
results in a TdTimestamp value of "2008-10-10 12:50:56.2123".
A can have a scale up to 7. A TdTimestamp has a maximum scale of 6. When performing an arithmetic operation, only the first 6 digits to the right of the decimal point of the TimeSpan operand will be considered. The 7th digit will be ignored.
