item.description:
Setting is true
All Day-Time intervals will return the .NET Framework Class Library data value of a .
All Year-Month intervals will return the .NET Framework Class Library data value of a . Setting is false
All intervals will return the .NET Framework Class Library data value of a .

description.para: Returns the Provider Specific Interval data value corresponding to the Teradata Database Interval data type.
All intervals will return the .NET Framework Class Library data value of a .

remarks.para: This feature has been added for backward compatibility with older applications. For example an older application, might have set to true and later assumed that the resulting columns in are of System.String type.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.RestrictToDefaultDatabase
member.summary: Indicates whether Schema queries should be restricted to the Default Database.
member.value: true restricts schema queries to the Default Database. Default value is false.

remarks.para: All Schema Collection queries are restricted to the Default Database () when this property is set to true. The Default Database can be set through the connection string and method.
Default Value: false

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.DataSourceDnsEntries
member.summary: The number of entries defined in DNS for the DataSource.

remarks.para: The .NET Data Provider will load balance between the DataSource entries found in DNS. The first connection attempt will choose a random number between 1 and DataSourceDnsEntries.
Default Value: undefined

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.NodeDownTimeout
member.summary: Obsolete. The number of seconds that must elapse before a connection attempt is made to a node previously marked as unavailable.

remarks.para: NOTE: This API is now obsolete. .NET Data Provider for Teradata uses a new algorithm to detect and bypass down nodes.

As the .NET Data Provider for Teradata load balances across the nodes, a node is marked unavailable if a connection attempt fails. The load balancing algorithm will skip a node that is marked unavailable until the timeout has expired.
Default Value: 900 seconds

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.UseEnhancedSchemaTable
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates whether method should return additional metadata information (e.g. IsKey and IsUnique).
member.value: The current value of UseEnhancedSchemaTable property, or the default value of true if none has been supplied.

remarks.para: This property controls whether the Data Provider should retrieve additional result set metadata from Teradata Database. This feature is available when connected to Teradata Database 6.2 or higher.
TdDataAdapter class can use the metadata to set properties and constraints on the DataTable. For example IsKey and IsUnique metadata fields are used to set constraints on a DataTable.

The TdDataAdapter.SelectCommand must return a Key in order for to generate UPDATE, INSERT and DELETE SQL commands when UseEnhancedSchemaTable is set to true and Teradata Database version is 6.2 or Higher. TdCommandBuilder will not require a Key when UseEnhancedSchemaTable is set to false or Teradata Database version 6.1 or earlier.
UseEnhancedSchemaTable property must be set to false for backward compatibility with Data Provider version 12.0 or earlier.
Default Value: true

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.QueryBand
member.summary: Gets or Sets the Query Bands that are to be defined at the Connection Level.
member.value: The current Query Band settings.

remarks.para: This property is used to define Query Bands at the Connection level. Refer to for more information.
The Query Banding feature is available when connected to Teradata Database 12.0 or higher.
Default Value: empty TdQueryBand instance

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.Recovery
member.summary: Sets Recoverable Network Protocol (RNP) and Redrive properties used during a network error or database failure.

remarks.para: There are 4 acceptable values:

item.description: Disables RNP and Redrive.
Enables Redrive participation as determined from the Teradata Active System Management (TASM) Redrive setting.
Enables the connection to reconnect in the event of a network error or database failure. Commands may be re-executed and results retrieved after reconnection from a network failure only.

Enables Redrive. The connection will participate in redriving commands after reconnection. Redrive enhances the RNP option, as the Teradata Database spool files are preserved after a database restart when REDRIVE is selected. Commands will be re-executed or restarted automatically from the Data Provider.

remarks.para: Default Value: DEFAULT

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.RecoveryTimeout
member.summary: Recovery timeout in seconds used to re-establish a connection.

remarks.para: The RecoveryTimeout is used if the CommandTimeout is infinite or the is enabled while the is non-zero.

If the CommandTimeout is 0, the reconnection timeout will always be extended by the RecoveryTimeout value in the application configuration file or the default value if not provided in the application configuration file.

If the CommandTimeout is non-zero, the reconnection timeout will be extended by the RecoveryTimeout value when RecoveryCommandTimeoutOverride is true. Otherwise if the RecoveryCommandTimeoutOverride is false and the CommandTimeout is finite, only the time remaining in the CommandTimeout will be used to reconnect.
Asynchronous commands do not contain or use CommandTimeouts. Asynchronous commands will always be use the RecoveryTimeout in reconnection.

The value of the RecoveryTimeout is determined based upon :
The RecoveryTimeout defined here
The RecoveryTimeout obtained from evaluating the
The default value

The event enables applications to change the RecoveryTimeout value that has been determined from the above hierarchy. The may be supplied by an application listening for the TdConnection.RecoverConnection event. It will always be activated during recovery in the initial attempt and during subsequent attempts after a calculated delay period. The TdConnection.RecoverConnection event is activated when either of the following is true during reconnection:
CommandTimeout is infinite
CommandTimeoutOverride is true
The command is asynchronous
If the event is activated again because the initial RecoveryTimeout expired, and the application is not listening, no additional time will be provided for reconnection and the reconnection will fail.
Default Value: 1200 seconds

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.ProfileName
member.summary: Specifies the profile name to access the appropriate properties from the application configuration file.

remarks.para: The profile name is used to set the supported properties from the application configuration file during execution. The supported TdConnection.ConnectionString properties are found in the Configuration File Provider Section.

The profile name must exist in the application configuration file. If the profile name does not exist the following error message will be returned - "Invalid connection string attribute: supplied profile name is not a valid value for Profile Name.", preventing a successful opening of the connection.
Default Value: null

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.CommandTimeout
member.summary: This sets the default command timeout.
member.remarks:
The CommandTimeout property represents the amount of time in seconds that the Data Provider waits for a response from Teradata. If the request is not processed within the specified CommandTimeout the request is aborted and the transaction is rolled back. A zero value indicates that the Data Provider should wait indefinitely for the SQL statement to execute.
The CommandTimeout property will be used during Redrive and Recoverable Network Protocol (RNP) support to determine additional time required to support Redrive and RNP. For more details see .
Default Value: 30 seconds

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.RecoveryCommandTimeoutOverride
member.summary: Enables a value to be supplied during reconnection for commands that contain a finite CommandTimeout.

remarks.para: All synchronous commands that contain a zero (infinite) will always extend the reconnection time by the RecoveryTimeout. If the CommandTimeout is non-zero, this new override property (when true) will set the reconnection timeout to the RecoveryTimeout value.
Default Value: true

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.RecoveryStartInterval
member.summary: The starting time interval (in seconds) after which an attempt to retry a reconnection is performed.

remarks.para: The RecoveryStartInterval is used to retry a reconnection that have encountered reconnectable errors. The RecoveryStartInterval is defined as the first time period to wait between unsuccessful efforts to reconnect. It is used to retry reconnection attempts.

The is used to modify the RecoveryStartInterval after the first retry is attempted, by adding the RecoveryIntervalFactor to the initial delay period. Each successive delay period will be modified by the RecoveryIntervalFactor until the delay period exceeds the . The RecoveryMaximumInterval is used to set the upper limit on the calculated delay period, until expires or the reconnection fails.

For example if the RecoveryStartInterval is 2 seconds, the RecoveryMaximumInterval is 16 and the RecoveryIntervalFactor is 2. The delay time between each retry attempt will be calculated as 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 12, 14, 16, 16, 16, etc. If the RecoveryIntervalFactor is 0, the RecoveryStartInterval will be used as the delay period for all retryable attempts, as the RecoveryIntervalFactor will not change the delay period.
Default Value: 2 seconds

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.RecoveryIntervalFactor
member.summary: This represents the adjustment in the recovery interval period from the preceeding interval period. The factor is an additive factor in seconds.

remarks.para: The RecoveryIntervalFactor will be added to the to create a new period of time to delay attempts to reconnect to the Teradata database.

The will limit the upper value of this period of time. For example, if the RecoveryStartInterval is 2, the RecoveryIntervalFactor is 2 and the RecoveryMaximumInterval is 32, the time periods generated internally will be 2, 4, 6, 8, until the maximum delay period of 32 is reached.
Default Value: 2

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.ConnectMaxRetryCount
member.summary: This represents the maximum number of attempts of a retryable error during before an error is returned to the application.

remarks.para: The ConnectMaxRetryCount will set the maximum number of retries for a connection attempt. Once this limit is reached, the connection will fail. For example if the value is set to 200, the Data Provider will retry 200 times before failing the connection attempt and the has not expired.
Default Value: 200

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.RecoveryMaximumInterval
member.summary: This represents the maximum interval time in seconds, used to limit the retry interval time adjusted by the .

remarks.para: The RecoveryMaximumInterval is the maximum interval of time to wait while attempting to reconnect to the database. If a RecoveryIntervalFactor is greater than 0, the RecoveryMaximumInterval will set the upper limit that may be used to delay attempts. When the RecoveryIntervalFactor is 0, the delay will always use the .
Default Value: 32 seconds

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdConnectionStringBuilder.EnforcePersistSecurityInfo
member.summary: Gets the ConnectionString; it removes the Password, New Password and Authentication String if the "Persist Security Info" is set to false.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdStream
member.summary: TdStream is used to retrieve a BLOB from Teradata Database.

remarks.para: TdStream represents a System.IO.Stream through which raw data (bytes) associated with a BLOB field can be read. Optionally, System.IO.BinaryReader and System.IO.StreamReader is used in conjunction with TdStream for reading of primitive .NET data types. TdStream does not support seeking; an application cannot modify the current position within the stream.

TdStream represents a read-only BLOB and an open query against the Teradata Database when CommandBehavior.SequentialAccess is not requested by the application. This query is separate and distinct from the query associated with the TdDataReader. Therefore the maximum number of open Teradata Database queries (16) limit applies to TdDataReader and TdStream. See TdBlob for additional information.

TdStream implements IDisposable interface. It is highly recommended that Dispose or Close be called before an instance of this class is released for garbage collection. Since garbage collection is not deterministic, valuable Teradata Database resources might not be released immediately. The TdStream is disposed when a TdBlob object is disposed.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdStream.Close
member.summary: Closes the TdStream object and frees all resources.
member.exception: The Teradata Database returned an error, or the .NET Data Provider for Teradata detected an error.
member.remarks: It frees all managed and unmanaged resource used by the TdStream object.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdStream.Flush
member.summary: Not supported.
member.exception: The Flush method is not supported.
member.remarks: TdStream is read-only and does not support the Flush method.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads data into the application provided buffer and advances the current position of the stream.
member.param: Specifies a Byte array to read data into.
Specifies the location within the buffer to read data into.
Specifies the number of bytes to read into the buffer
member.returns: Returns the number of bytes read from Teradata Database and written into the . The number will be equal or less than .
member.exception: is null.

exception.para: or is negative or the sum of and is larger than the length.

member.exception: The is closed.
The TdStream is closed / dispose.
The Teradata Database returned an error, or the .NET Data Provider for Teradata detected an error.
member.remarks: The .NET Data Provider for Teradata reads the LOB from Teradata and transfers it to the application provided buffer.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: TdStream does not support seeking.
member.param: Specifies the number of bytes relative to origin.
Designates a reference point within the stream.
member.exception: The TdStream does not support seeking.
member.returns: Returns a new position within the stream

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: TdStream does not support seeking.
member.param: Specifies the length of TdStream in bytes.
member.exception: The TdStream does not support seeking.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdBlob
member.summary: TdBlob represents a BLOB (Binary Large Object) data type instance. It is used to retrieve a BLOB from the Teradata database.

remarks.para: TdBlob does not expose any public constructor. It's primary purpose is to retrieve BLOB data from the Teradata database.
In order to create an instance of TdBlob, method must be called when the data contained in a BLOB column is to be retrieved.

When a TdBlob is created, the provider will open a request on the existing connection. This request is separate and independent from the request that was opened to process the query. The Teradata Database has a maximum number of open requests that it can support per connection. The limit is 16.

It is important that or is called after the TdBlob has been used to process the BLOB. This will free up the resources and the request that was used to retrieve the BLOB from the Teradata Database. After a TdBlob is disposed, an application can only call the Close, Dispose or the IsClosed. All other methods and properties will throw a ObjectDisposedException exception.

A TdBlob instance can only be created when the BLOB data is retrieved using deferred mode. This allows the data to be streamed from the Teradata Database to the Data Provider, and allows an application to retrieve the data in chunks from one or more LOBs.
BLOB data is returned using deferred mode when has not been specified in the call to .
returns a stream. An application can read primitve .NET Framework data types from a using a . TdStream does not support seeking.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdClob
member.summary: TdClob represents a CLOB (Character Large Object) data type instance. It is used to retrieve CLOB data from the Teradata Database.

remarks.para: TdClob does not expose any public constructor. It's primary purpose is to retrieve CLOB data from the Teradata database.
In order to create an instance of TdClob, method must be called when the data contained in a CLOB column is to be retrieved.

When a TdClob is created, the provider will open a request on the existing connection. This request is separate and independent from the request that was opened to process the query. The Teradata Database has a maximum number of open requests that it can support per connection. The limit is 16.

It is important that or is called after the TdClob has been used to process the CLOB. This will free up the resources and the request that was used to retrieve the CLOB from the Teradata Database. After a TdClob is disposed, an application can only call the Close and Dispose methods or the IsClosed property. All other methods and properties will throw an ObjectDisposedException exception.

A TdClob instance can only be created when the CLOB data is retrieved using deferred mode. This allows the data to be streamed from the Teradata Database to the Data Provider, and allows an application to retrieve the data in chunks from one or more LOBs.
An application is unable to access the base stream of the TdClob instance.
CLOB data is returned using deferred mode when has not been specified in the call to .

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter
member.summary: Represents a parameter to a SQL statement.

remarks.para: Parameterized SQL statements accept one or more input parameters (data). TdParameter represents the data value and can be associated with objects using property. TdParameter describes the .NET data type and the corresponding Teradata column type. The data provider converts .NET data types to Teradata data types before it is sent to Teradata Database for processing. The data provider cannot derive parameter data type information from Teradata when the TdCommand is prepared. Therefore, the data provider relies on information provided by the TdParameter object or it implicitly maps the .NET data type to Teradata data type.

Teradata Stored Procedures also support output and input-output parameters. TdParameter can correctly map .NET data types to Teradata data types and back and therefore fully support Input, Input-Output and Output parameters to SQL statements.
The data provider does not support the USING CLAUSE. All SQL statements should use parameter markers (Question Mark) as oppose to USING CLAUSE and parameter names prefixed with the colon character.
It is highly recommended to use parameterized queries in order to take advantage of the Teradata Statement-Cache. See the Teradata SQL manual for additional information.
For information on how to specify a LOB as a parameter please refer to

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.DbType
member.summary: Gets or sets the generic (ADO.NET) data type of the parameter.
member.value: One of the System.Data.DbType enumeration values. The default is String.
member.exception: Argument is not a valid DbType.
member.remarks: System.Data.DbType is a generic data type enumeration. In this context it specifies the parameter type of the target column or arguments to a stored procedure. It is recommended that you use the property to specify the parameter data type. The data provider automatically changes the TdParameter.DbType property when the property is set.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Direction
member.summary: Gets and sets the parameter direction. It indicates whether the parameter is passed to the Teradata Database as input, returned from the Teradata Database as output, or sent to and returned from the Teradata Database as input and output.
member.value: One of the System.Data.ParameterDirection enumeration values. The default is Input"/>
member.exception: Argument is not a valid ParameterDirection
member.remarks: ParameterDirection.InputOutput and ParameterDirection.Output apply only to Teradata stored proceduers. Output parameters reflect the stored procedure results after the specific result set(s) is processed. For example, the output parameters to a stored procedure represented as the third statement in a multi-statement request are not available while application is processing the first and the second result set. In this case the output parameters are available after the second call to TdDataReader.NextResult. If executes the command, then the data provider processes all result sets and populates the output parameters.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.IsNullable
member.summary: Indicates whether the Value property can be set to DbNull.
member.value: true if TdParameter.Value can be set to DbNull and false otherwise. The default value is false

remarks.para: Every parameter sent to Teradata has a specific data type, for example INTEGER. IsNullable property is used as a Teradata data_type_attribute, for example INTEGER NOT NULL.
IsNullable attribute has no impact on the Value property. That is can always be set to System.DbNull.Value by the application or the Data Provider (output parameter).

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.ParameterName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the TdParameter object.
member.value: The name of the TdParameter object. The default is an empty string.

remarks.para: class uses the as an indexer. Furthermore, ParameterName is used in Teradata Stored Procedure CALL statement generation. The data provider generates a CALL SQL statement when the is set to StoredProcedure. The CALL statement requires output parameter names. For additional information see Teradata Manipulation Statements manual.
The Teradata Database does not support named parameters. Therefore, the position of parameters within the TdParameterCollection dictates the order in which parameters are sent to Teradata.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.SourceColumn
member.summary: Maps a DataTable column to and from the TdParameter object.
member.value: Contains the name of the source column in a .
member.remarks: This is the link between the and a . For input parameters, Data is moved from the to the parameter before the command is executed. For output parameters, data is moved /// from the parameter to the . See the method for additional information on how to resolve changes to a DataSet back to Teradata tables.

member.summary: Gets or sets the DataRowVersion to use when loading a DataTable column into the TdParameter object.

member.exception: Argument is not a valid DataRowVersion.
member.remarks: The TdDataAdapter.Update method uses this value to determine the corresponding DataRow column value to be assigned to the property. Usually the parameters passed to the WHERE clause of the SQL statement assigned to the property carry the Original values. Original values are used to identify the row.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the TdParameter object.
member.value: Specifies an object reference. The default value is null.

remarks.para: For input parameters, the Value property is converted into the TdType before data is transmitted to the Teradata Database.

The Teradata type is inferred from the Value property if TdType is not specified by the application. .NET primitive data types are mapped and converted to Teradata data types; for example System.Int32 data type is mapped to Teradata INTEGER data type by default. For additional information see Converting Data from .NET to Teradata Data Types.

The data provider uses the IConvertible interface for all non-primitive types assigned to the Value property. The data provider first casts the Value property to IConvertible and then invokes a method corresponding to the Teradata data type (for example: IConvertible.ToInt32). The invariant culture (System.Globalization.CultureInfo.InvariantCulture) is used for data type conversions.

To assign a null value (Teradata Database NULL as oppose to null object reference) to a parameter, set the Value property to the System.DBNull.Value property. A null object reference is not the same as System.DBNull. The data provider does not support null object references. Therefore a execution results in an exception if one of the associated properties is set to a null object reference.
The Value property is overwritten if Direction property is set to InputOutput or Output. TdType, Precision, Scale and Size properties are updated to reflect the returned parameter value.

When a BLOB/CLOB is specified as an Input parameter, the Value property must be set to an object that the provider can use to read the data of the LOB. The provider can read the data of a BLOB using one of the following objects:

item.description: Any object that derives from Stream can be used.

remarks.para: When the input parameter is a CLOB, the provider can read the data when one of the following type of objects are used:

item.description: Any object that derives from TextReader can be used.

remarks.para: When a LOB has been specified as an output parameter, a , or will be returned depending upon whether the TdType has been set to TdType.Blob, TdType.Clob/Json or TdType.Xml respectively.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.SourceColumnNullMapping
member.summary: Indicates whether the source column is nullable.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Precision
member.summary: Gets and sets the precision of numeric, datetime and interval data types.

remarks.para: The table below defines for each data type:

td.para: Precision is the number of digits before and after the decimal point.
Precision is total number of characters which defines a Date Time data type. For example a value of '1999-05-05 09:20:30.5' will contain a precision of 21.
Precision is defined as the number of digits within the significant field. For example a value of '923 12:20:30.5' will contain a precision of 3, the number of digits contained within the day field.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Scale
member.summary: Indicates the scale of numeric, date time and interval data types.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size for the transmitted data

remarks.para: The Size property represents the number of bytes for nonstring data types and ANSI string data. For Unicode strings, the size is used to indicate the number of characters.

The Size property will have a different meaning when the property is set to DbType.AnsiString or DbType.String. When the the DbType property is set to AnsiString the Size represents the number of bytes of the string. In the case where the DbType is String, the Size represents the number of characters contained in the string.

When creating a parameter for character array or string, the application programmer must be cognizant of what the Session Character Set is being used when logging into the Teradata database. In this situation it is important to understand when to specify the number of bytes or number of characters when using the Teradata data provider.

For example, if a column in a table is defined with the server character sets Kanjisjis or Kanji1, any parameters that will refer to these columns must have the DbType property set to DbType.AnsiString. The value of Size must represent the number of bytes of the string to be sent to Teradata
The following are descriptions of additional scenarios and their expected behavior:

Scenario: A table that contains a column defined as VARCHAR(20) CHARACTER SET KANJISJIS. The size of this column is defined in terms of bytes (please refer to the "SQL Reference: Data Types and Literals" for more information). The Session Character Set has been set to UTF16 and the character array contains only ASCII data.
Expected Behavior: Each character in the array will take two bytes of space after being encoded using UTF16. If the Size has been set to 4, only two characters of the array will be sent to Teradata.

Scenario: This applies when connected to a Teradata Database 12.0 or earlier. A stored procedure contains a parameter declared as VARCHAR(20) CHARACTER SET LATIN, and the session character set has been set to UTF8. The session mode is ANSI. In the application, the DbType is set to DbType.String and the character array contains ASCII characters. The Size has been set to 11.

Expected Behavior: The data that will be passed to Teradata will contain 22 bytes (two bytes for each ASCII character after being encoded using UTF8). The Teradata database will return an error indicating the string will be truncated.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Offset
member.summary: Gets or sets the index within the Value property where the read / write operation is to begin. Usually used with BLOB and or CLOB.
member.value: Offset into the Value property. The default is 0.
member.remarks: Offset is the index into the Value property where the read (input parameter) and write (output parameter) operation is to begin. It is ignored if the Value property is of a fixed length and not an array. For example Offset indicates the starting element within Byte[] type.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.TdType
member.summary: Gets or sets the TdType (Teradata type) of the parameter.
member.value: One of the TdType enumeration values. The default is Char.
member.exception: Argument is not a valid TdType.

remarks.para: TdType property specifies the data type of the target column or arguments to a stored procedure. It is strongly recommended that you use the property to specify the parameter data type. The data provider automatically changes the property when you set the TdParameter.TdType property. The property is converted into the TdType before data is transmitted to the Teradata Database.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.ProviderSpecificValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the TdParameter object.
member.value: Specifies an object reference. The default value is null.

remarks.para: Returns .NET Data Provider for Teradata specific data types like , and . It returns Framework Class Library (FCL) types when there is no corresponding provider specific type. For example it returns for Teradata Integer data type.
.NET Data Provider for Teradata data types implement interface. property must be used to check for null. FCL types do not support INullable, therefore null is represented by .

Some of the provider specific types supported by the provider have a corresponding "Enable" Connection String Attribute. The setting of this attribute will affect the behavior of this property. Refer to the Enabling Provider Specific Types section of the Developers Guide for further information.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.SecondaryTdType
member.summary: Gets or sets the TdType, when the TdType value is defined as a TdType.Array or a TdType.AnyType.

remarks.para: This property introduced by Teradata Database 14.0, defines the TdType when the actual TdType property is either TdType.Array or TdType.AnyType. TdArray will contain TdType elements of this property and TdType.AnyType is an indicator that the actual TdType will be defined at execution time by this property.
This property for TD_ANYTYPE OUT parameters generates a RESULT clause to define the OUT parameter type to the database in generation of the CALL statement for stored procedures.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.OutValue

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameter.Parent

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdParameterCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of objects associated with a object.

remarks.para: Parameterized SQL statements accept one or more input parameters (). represents the data value and can be associated with objects using property. is an instance of TdParameterCollection and holds all input, inputoutput and output parameters.
It is highly recommended that parameterized queries be used in order to take advantage of the Teradata Statement-Cache. See the Teradata SQL manual for additional information.

member.name: T:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction
member.summary: Represents an Explicit Teradata Database Transaction. It should be explicitly committed or rolled back.
member.remarks:
By default object operates in Auto-Commit mode. Therefore the transaction spans the execution of one or more object. The application can open a transaction via and explicitly control when the transaction is committed or rolled back.
Teradata Database will rollback a transaction when a SQL statement results in a specific set of errors. In this case, the .NET Data Provider for Teradata will open a new explicit transaction and the TdTransaction object can be used to commit or abort the remaining activities associated with the object.
The object reverts back to Auto-Commit mode after an explicit call by the application to
or method.
Unlike the ODBC Driver and OLE DB Provider for Teradata, the .NET Data Provider for Teradata does not automatically commit a transaction after a DDL statement execution. Therefore, the DDL statement has to be the last SQL statement within a transaction. Furthermore the DDL statement cannot be part of a multi-statement request.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.Commit
member.summary: Commits the transaction and re-enables the Auto-Commit mode.
member.exception: Object is disposed and the transaction has already been committed or rolled back.
The Teradata Database returned an error, or .NET Data Provider for Teradata detected an error.
member.remarks: The Commit method commits the transaction (unit of work) and forces the back into Auto-Commit mode. It also disassociates the TdTransaction from the TdConnection object. The Connection property will return a Null reference after the call to the Commit method.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.Rollback
member.summary: Rolls back the transaction and re-enables the Auto-Commit mode.
member.exception: Object is disposed and the transaction has already been committed or rolled back.
The Teradata Database returned an error, or .NET Data Provider for Teradata detected an error.
member.remarks: The Rollback method aborts the transaction (unit of work) and forces the back into Auto-Commit mode. It also disassociates the TdTransaction from the TdConnection object. The Connection property will return a Null reference after the call to the Rollback method.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.Close
member.summary: Rolls back the transaction and enables the Auto-Commit mode.
member.remarks: It aborts the transaction and releases all unmanaged resources.

member.name: M:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.ChangeQueryBand(Teradata.Client.Provider.TdQueryBand)
member.summary: The Transaction Level Query Bands are modified to those defined in .
member.param: The Query Bands that will be defined at the Transaction Level.
member.exception: Query Bands or Trusted Sessions are not supported by the Teradata Database.
Transaction is not opened.
is null.

remarks.para: Query Bands are only supported when connecting to a Teradata Database 12.00 or later releases.
When this method is called, a "SET QUERY_BAND ... FOR TRANSACTION" statement is submitted to the Teradata Database. The old settings are removed, and the new settings are created.
The Transaction Level Query Band is set to NONE when the input parameter has Zero ( is equal to zero) Key-Value pairs.
The Query Bands that have been defined at the Connection level are still active during the transaction.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.System#Data#IDbTransaction#Connection
member.summary: Gets the IDbConnection object associated with this transaction.
member.value: The IDbConnection object associated with this transaction.
member.remarks: Connection property returns the active TdConnection associated with this transaction. After a call to the Commit or Rollback method, the transaction is no longer associated with a TdConnection object and TdTransaction is in disposed state.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.IsolationLevel
member.summary: Gets the session isolation level associated with the transaction.
member.value: The isolation level of the current transaction.
member.exception: Object is disposed and the transaction has already been committed or rolled back.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.Connection
member.summary: Gets the TdConnection object associated with this transaction.
member.value: The TdConnection object associated with this transaction or a Null reference.
member.remarks: Connection property returns the active associated with this transaction. After a call to the or methods, the transaction is no longer associated with a TdConnection object and Connection returns a Null reference.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.QueryBand
member.summary: Gets the TdQueryBand object that contains the definitions of the Query Bands that have been defined at the Transaction level.
member.returns: The TdQueryBand object that contains the definitions of the Transaction level Query Bands.

remarks.para: Query Bands are only supported in Teradata Database 12.0 or greater.
The Query Bands that have been defined at the Connection level are still active during the transaction.

member.name: P:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdTransaction.DbConnection
member.summary: Gets the DbConnection object associated with this transaction.
member.value: The DbConnection object associated with this transaction or a Null reference.
member.remarks: DbConnection property returns the active associated with this transaction. After a call to the or methods, the transaction is no longer associated with a DbConnection object and DbConnection returns a Null reference.

16 bit signed integer. Ranging from -32,768 to 32,767.
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.Int16SMALLINT

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.Time
member.summary:
Time value with HH:mm:ss.(f) format. Teradata supports up to 6 fractional-seconds-precision (i.e. TIME(6)).
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.TimeTIME

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.TimeWithZone
member.summary:
Time With Time Zone value with HH:mm:ss.(f)HH:mm format. Teradata supports up to 6 fractional-seconds-precision (i.e. TIME(6)). Note that Time with Time Zone can be cast to Time and is correctly adjusted to represent local time.
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.StringTIME WITH TIME ZONE

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.Timestamp
member.summary:
Timestamp (date + time) value with yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss.(f) format. Ranging from 0001-01-01 00:00:00.000000 to 9999-12-31 23:59:59.999999. Teradata supports up to 6 fractional-seconds-precision (i.e. TIMESTAMP(6)).
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.DateTimeTIMESTAMP

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.TimestampWithZone
member.summary:
Timestamp With Time Zone value with yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.(f)ZHH:mm format. Teradata supports up to 6 fractional-seconds-precision (i.e. TIMESTAMP(6) WITH TIME ZONE). Note that Timestamp with Time Zone can be cast to Timestamp and is correctly adjusted to represent local time.
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.DateTimeOffsetTIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.VarByte
member.summary:
Represents a variable-length binary data VARBYTE(n) where n is the number of bytes ranging from 1 to 64000.
Application calls to retrieve all or a portion of the binary data.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.BinaryVARBYTE

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.VarChar
member.summary:
Represents a variable-length character string. Teradata automatically translates between the session character set and target column.
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.StringVARCHAR, LONG VARCHAR

member.name: F:Teradata.Client.Provider.TdType.VarGraphic
member.summary:
Represents a variable-length UNICODE character string. GRAPHIC represents Unicode characters defined by IBM corporation for DB2.
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:
DbTypeTeradata Data Type
DbType.StringVARGRAPHIC, LONG VARGRAPHIC

summary.para: A Period of type TdDate that has a format of ('beginning bound', 'ending bound'). Both the beginning and ending bounds have the format yyyy-MM-dd.
Application call to retrieve the value.

Application call to retrieve the value.

item.description: PERIOD(TIME)

Application call to retrieve the value.

Application call to retrieve the value.

summary.para: A Period of type TdTimeWithTimeZone that has a format of ('beginning bound', 'ending bound'). Both the beginning and ending bounds have the format HH:mm:ss.(f)HH:mm. The scale can range from 0 to 6.

summary.para: Represents an object (i.e. Parameter) whose data type is defined at runtime. It is conceptually similar to a Variant type.
The TD_ANYTYPE type is supported as a parameter type for functions (domain specific system functions and UDFs), user defined methods and external stored procedures (XSPs).

Number represents a Teradata type NUMBER. The corresponding provider specific type is TdNumber. The range of a NUMBER is [1E-130 to 9.999E125] as well as 0. It will also support a precision of up to 40 digits.
Application calls to retrieve the value.
Type Mappings:

item.description: NUMBER

summary.para: Xml represents a Xml document or fragment.
